description:
brunch review. 3-course menu.

4 - basket of breads
(seasonal fruit preserve, sweet ricotta, almond butter)
(fiscalini cheddar, chicken liver mousse, bread & butter pickles)

3 - shortrib frittata

5 - fried chicken
(country gravy & eggs)

4 - apple doughnuts

5 - puffed potatoes & eggs
(cauliflower mousse, crispy bacon, parmesan)

overall, "as good as it gets."
author: Mark O.

description:
We've had this place bookmarked forever, and was pretty disappointed today.  2.5 on food, but bumped up for good service and ease of reservations.

Food-

Burrata and heirloom squash - pretty tasty, best burrata I've had.

$3 house bread and butter. This was so basic, they should have just given it for free.

perfect potatoes was pretty in pictures but was just basic when you ate it. It was basically a croquette with puréed cauliflower underneath.

The chicken liver mousse was a hard pass. It was super salty and the bread was so burnt it was black.

The squid ink pasta was super al dente the seafood was so tiny and so over cooked it was extra rubbery.

The uni carbonara was watery and was sitting in a puddle of water.

Food presentation was awesome though and looks great for all of our Instagram photos. However the flavors just were very basic and it was not well done.

The worst part was no choco taco!!! It's the first picture on their Yelp and the one thing I was really looking forward too.

In comparison to other restaurants of this style, I'd have to say Frances is better.
author: Vi Y.

description:
Great spot! Location is awesome, right on hyde, few blocks away from polk. Went for a birthday party on a Friday night and we had reserved a large table in the back.

We mostly had appetizers through the night but everything was incredible especially the puffed potato and eggs, DELICIOUS as well as the Squid Ink pasta and Octopus were both top notch. On top of that the wine we had was perfect with our food and it always seemed like there was a server there to refill or provide assistance without being overbearing. Definitely seemed like a great date spot and I can see myself coming back!
author: Matthew O.

description:
A fantastic experience. We came here for dinner on a Saturday evening (and had a reservation, so we were seated immediately). We started off with the puffed potato and eggs, and firebrand bread. The puffed potato and eggs were to die for, absolutely delicious. The firebrand bread, was good, but it was bread. I typically like my bread pretty soft and this one was a bit more chewy, so wasn't a huge fan but I slathered a ton of butter on it which made it more than satisfactory. 

We tried the heirloom melon and cucumber salad, hamachi crudo and squid ink conchiglie pasta from the starter section. The heirloom salad had "burrata" in the description so I anticipated it looking like a burrata dish. The pieces of burrata were so small that I almost missed them... the salad was good but be warned, it's really not a lot of burrata included in the dish. The starters were a little hard to split between 4 people just because they were so tiny. The hamachi crudo was good, I've had a lot better fish but it's always been at top tier sushi restaurants. The squid ink conchiglie pasta was absolutely fantastic, one of the highlights of the night for sure (besides the potato dish from earlier). 

The pan-seared halibut and waygu were the mains that we ordered and came out last. I'm not a big halibut person so I'm probably the wrong person to review this dish, I thought it was just "ok", nothing special about it. The waygu steak was fantastic, significantly more up my alley than the fish was. 

Quick mention for our drinks, I ordered some kind of peach cocktail and expected it to be very fruity and sweet. I must have missed the part where it states it has jalepeno, so instead it was incredibly spicy... I'm not a big fan of spicy so I spent the whole meal delicately sipping this one. The desserts we ordered were the chocolate cake, peaches and cream and the peanut butter and jelly donuts. We were warned that the chocolate cake was rich, and boy, was the waitress right. I could only take a few bites of it before I had to switch to another dish because of the richness. The peach custard looked and tasted like mochi ice cream, it was tasty but I couldn't see it as anything special because it really just seemed like mochi ice cream to me. The peanut butter and jelly donuts were great. The donuts tasted and felt like beignets, with peanut butter and jelly to accompany them.

The restaurant was a bit expensive for what you get, but all in all, a good experience. Except the part where the waitress was cleaning the table and knocked over a wine glass, but she kindly refilled it and apologized, accidents happen :).
author: Katie Y.

description:
July 29,2018 Update: 

I came back here with friends to see how this place changed after they replaced their main chefs and am happy to say that it's still an exceptional restaurant that I feel is one of the best in the city in its price range. We tried literally every item on the menu except the tomato soup, risotto, and bread and almost every single item was a unique delight to the senses. I felt the pastas were the weak point in their menu (except the ravioli which had one of the best textures and fillings I've ever had in ravioli) and the burger could've been improved with a slightly coarser grind but these were minor complaints to an otherwise spectacular meal. I highly recommend the strawberry rhubarb non-alcoholic cocktail.
author: Andrew H.

description:
How cute is this place?! 
Aside from the lovely ambiance and warm lighting, the food was wonderful.

* Puffed potato and eggs ($8) - GET THIS APPETIZER! Four glorious potato and egg yolk mashed balls to give a creamy consistency in every bite. Over a spread of cauliflower mousse with shaved chives. This is perfection!

* Hamachi crudo ($15) - Fresh hamachi. Can't complain. Beautiful presentation.

* Pasta & shortrib sugo ($24) - Shortrib was tender and flavorful, but not too salty. The cooked to perfection campanelle pasta was like an upgrade from the usual fusilli. 

Would 10/10 come back here again! This place gives me date night vibes from head to toe.
author: Vickie Z.

description:
Excellent Brunch. We've been looking for a place to get a good, reasonably priced brunch without chaos and hours waiting. Stone's Throw is definitely that place, only we'd say the brunch is much better than good. They take reservations which helps keep the atmosphere manageable.

Atmosphere: relaxed casual, NOT loud but the place was full, trestle table in the center with a large centerpiece. Simple. The focus is on the food, but the atmosphere is quietly doing its part (and it has a very nice bar). Windows overlook Hyde street. Mostly banquette seating, but our neighbors were not unbearably close.

Service: Hi Neighbor has got the service down. Having visited their other restaurants one of their biggest pluses is the friendliness and knowledge-ability of the staff. But, the restaurant is also run with group service. So your glass is constantly being filled, dirty plates are whisked away, and you aren't trying to flag down YOUR waiter.  To add to the efficient service, the staff is very friendly and comfortable without being intrusive.

Food: Amazing brunch, really. I can't say enough about the flavors (and none of them were the "usual brunch" favs). There's a prix fix $20 menu and some additional sides (add the potatoes stuffed with egg with a cauliflower puree--this is to die for. And I would eat that as my meal-but the other dishes are sooo . . . good). The meal starts with a bread basket, jam, ricotta and nut butter (you could also have cheddar, pate and pickles). This was the least amazing, not that it wasn't good, but save room for the mains. We especially like the sour dough bread (and the strawberry jam is literally like pure strawberry flavor).

For our second course, we had the fried chicken that is served with a sausage gravy and two beautifully poached eggs. Huge amount of food, but we ate almost the entire thing. Fried chicken has a very mild tarragon flavor that really sets it above other similar dishes. And getting a bite of the chicken with gravy and egg is a flavor sensation. And, we ordered the ham and cheese sandwich. We could not decide which we preferred and decided they were both great. The ham and cheese is on a brioche bun slathered with pimento cheese with just a hint of heat topped with a real slice of ham (not sliced ham) and an egg. And there is some kind of amazing relish underlying the whole shebang that puts this dish outside the league of most ham and cheese sandwiches. I am guessing some kind of sliced turnips though don't quote me on that, but it was such a great compliment to the sandwich.

The third course surprised me. I'm not a donut eater and the course was billed as peach donuts. But, it was not really a donut. It was more like a beignet (but not a beignet either). It's not light but it's not heavy. It's covered with a sugar glaze and nuts (I think I'd like it without the sugar glaze. For me, it distracted from the other flavors). It sits on a thick peach jam.

They also have a great wine and beer list organized around flavors not grapes. And offer a few cocktails like a mimosa and a Pimm's cup.

Looking for a perfect foodie overnight in the city? Start at Trestle (another hi neighbor restaurant that's amazing) for dinner, then head to City Lights book store and soak up some San Francisco history (City Lights is 65 years old and has some of the best curated books around.)  Then head to Stones Throw for brunch the next day. That's the kind of twofer people dream about!
author: Vivek V.

description:
Came here to celebrate a birthday with a friend and this restaurant puts an effort to make your occasion very special. They actually write a little happy birthday card and offered us a complimentary birthday dessert. 

Stones throw is a cute little restaurant that has a small but flavorful menu. For appetizers we got the potato and egg balls and the hamachi crudo. For mains we got the pasta with short rib sauce and the steak. Everything we had was good. The hamachi had fried onion crisps on top and served with avocado cream I believe?  It was fresh and tart and the fish was delicious. The potato and egg balls were interesting. Had great flavor and tasted like breakfast :). 

The pasta was delicious. The sauce reminded me of a slow cooked bolognese and the short rib was pieces were tender and juicy. The steak was a little on the chewy side but it was cooked perfectly. The sauce it came with didn't add to much to the dish but overall it was a very filling entree. 

Would definitely come back. Service was great and food was great.
author: Suzanne W.

description: Extremely poor service. If you want to have breakfast on a timer then this is the place for you. We made reservations, in advance, for four. My family traveled abroad (Belgium) and wanted to see the family one last time before their flight. The lady at the front did accommodate us but said we have to finish our entire 3 course meal in 45 minutes. Who says that? When we had reservations for 4 already. We felt so stressed throughout our entire course as the server came up to us constantly asking if we were finished. It was just a very classless experience. Highly not recommended.
author: Roxanne O.

description:
Oki doki, this ones gonna be a doozy.

Firstly, our seating location faced gorgeous trees that shadowed over a 2 road spectacular. There were smiling people passing by, puppies prancing, the whole 10 yards. 

Secondly, all the staff including the head chef came out to ya several times. One to share their incredibly precise tableware placement, but to greet and create connection.

Thirdly, 'Anotha Chelada' we got to meet the creator, and, she knows how to do a chelada. It was balanced, brilliant and like the meal, was filled with natural fresh ingredients.

Fourth, the chicken and gravy, the egg sandwich and get the bacon(it stands by itself). 

Come for the people, leave fulfilled in every possible way from the food and celebrate that you experienced on of the best values of your life. 

Thank you Stone Way, we'll see you soon.

Love always, 
Kyle & Zoey
author: Kyle E.

description:
The food is so good here!! Why the 4 stars? Because I have to say the portions are so tiny, especially for the price. I had an appetizer, entree and dessert and was still not *full*. I bet the guys at our party were still completely starving.

On to the food: The puffed potato and egg "snack" melts in your mouth. Very unexpected and sooo yummy. Shrimp ceviche was tasty too. Different than most ceviches. Mushroom ragu and pea risotto were both way too salty. My scallops were good but nothing spectacular. The dessert menu exceeded my expectations. Based off of childhood food memories... so cute. We ordered a few different items including their "peanut butter and jelly donut"--which are actually beignets with splashes of pb&j. Sooo yummy. Fresh, light and fluffy pillows of fried dough. The Fudgsicle was a treat to the eyes and tastebuds. Chocolate and kiwi bits with black sesame chunks. Very creative. I loved it. 

I'd say come here and try the starters, snacks and dessert. None of our mains were that special, but everything else made up for it.
author: Athena L.

description:
As Oliver Twist did say, "please sir, I want some more".  

Give me some more of that stellar hospitality that Stones Throw staff exemplify.  They're masters at the art of making one feel warm and welcome.  When I called less than 90 minutes before my 7 p.m. reservation, asking if they could take my party of four 30 minutes later than planned on a Saturday night, they couldn't have been more gracious with their response.  I didn't catch even a whiff of my request being unreasonable.  

Give me more too, of that beautifully prepared food.  My party gamely tried to sample as many dishes as possible and we put quite a dent in the menu.  Alas though, this would not be Canteen (RIP), where we actually did once order the entire menu and still recall the experience with excitement.  Here, we found Stones Throw dishes to be lovely in presentation and tasty, each a little jewel box of delight.  

Please do give me more of the actual food though, particularly the starters and snacks.  I was saddened to have only a small bite of Citrus Poached Shrimp ($10) and Hamachi Crudo.  Perhaps the kitchen could up the price and quantity when they know that a dish will be shared amongst 4.  

So:  Stellar hospitality, beautiful presentation, and delicious food though maybe less than you desire.  What's a person to do?

Da' Burger.  

Actually, Da' Burger and the desserts are a good way to ensure you leave here sated (but also, just because it's great, don't miss the Squid Ink Conchiglie Pasta, $17).  The kitchen quartered Da' Burger for our table and in addition to being fabulous, it provided the satisfying fullness I sought.  Get it.  

Celebrating 3 birthdays mandated at least 3 desserts in addition to the already consumed cocktails and two bottles of wine.  We went big then went home.  The Rhubarb Cheesecake briefly looked too pretty to eat but proved not so.  Down the gullet; Great and wildly creative desserts.

Stones Throw is a delightful place to celebrate.  It doesn't look like anything much but the enthusiastic staff and the perfectly executed creations turn it into something quite sweet that'll leave you, as me, wanting more of it all.
author: Tracey A.

description: This has to be one of the best restaurants I have been to in a long while. Originally went to SF to go to Crustaceans for my boyfriend's birthday,  but missed our reservation. After driving around and yelping/googling different restaurants still open at 10pm, we came across Stones Throw. When we got there, my boyfriend and I were definitely not expecting the experience we had. We had an absolute blast with our friends that came out to celebrate and the staff was sooooooo nice and knowledgeable. I believe our waiter's name was Jessie James, he was awesome! Will be back again.
author: CharneefaRay D.

description:
Stones throw is a wonderful restaurant in a great neighborhood I adore.

The four of us tasted many of the starters and all were amazing....so good we wish they were larger portions.

Perhaps my only complaint was: There wasn't more in our portions ( I know I sound like a whiner)!

Execution is flawless. The three starters:  Citrus poached shrimp, Puffed potato and egg, and Duck liver mouse were all amazing!!!  Beautiful to look out. Complex and flavorful to taste. We all were blown away.

The main courses did not let down as well. My trio of Pork was pig nirvana. Each cooked perfectly and the garnishes added to the overall dishes flavor and texture.

The Scallops in Dashi were flawlessly executed! Crisp on the outside silky on the inside. All veggies incorporated into the dish were marvelous.

The last main was a pasta with shortrib. As was the others..perfectly executed.

Service was amazing. Everyone there is so nice and pleasant. Our waiter had a wonderful personality and made great suggestions without being overbearing.

Wine list is great and there is something there for almost everyone. Prices are pretty reasonable!

We only had one dessert    (Peanut butter and Jelly donuts...wonderful fun dish btw!)  but we did have some dessert beers ( now that was weird and cool...at the same time).

Overall I would definitely recommend.

Parking is horrible in this neighborhood say take an Lyft!
author: David G.

description:
The food's fantastic, the ambiance is dark and engaging, and I'm definitely torn between 3 and 4 stars.

Simply put, I felt that there's just not enough wow for how much effort you'll need to dine here. Reservations aren't too difficult, but they will call you the day before + text you the day of, which I understand is to make sure those who reserve actually show up; but it makes me feel like a lot of people no-show this place (despite the food... we'll get there.)

(Parking is also notably tough here, so you'll either have to luck out or Lyft.)

Now comes the speed... our party was fully present at 8:20 for an 8:15 reservation, and I'm pretty sure we started eating around 9pm. The servers were definitely very nice, but it's hard to enjoy even that when you're hangry after 40 minutes. There isn't any bread or anything like that, so it's just  the sporadic "we'll be with you in a moment" until they actually do come.

As for the food, the menu changes quarterly - and the potato puffs are definitely fantastic (definitely must-try). Everything else is probably pretty good honestly, though keep in mind that the portion is really small. Like if you wanted to eat heartily, you may want to consider getting 2-3 mains per person. If you're a big eater, maybe your own snack, your own starter, and 2 mains will be okay. 

That being said, Stones Throw is a really good place to try something great if you're a local (since parking/Lyft is less of an issue). If you're entertaining folks of out town or want more bang for your buck, there are definitely many places that trump Stones Throw in both quality and quantity.
author: Greg G.

description: Oh my goodness where to begin- absolutely magnificent! Love the space, it's inviting and edgy, and even though the tables seem to be very close it somehow doesn't matter because it still allows personal space within your party. Magic? Yes. A lot of creative menu ideas that were all absolutely fabulous. Plus a helpful guide to lead us every step of the way. My first adventure was the watermelon salad with burrata and spiced nuts. Every bite was delicious and it kept the palate intrigued. The second stop was the seared beef with pickled vegetables. The beef was cooked perfect and the sourness from the vegetables added an extra pop to the dish. The last stop was fun and engaging; they ask you to write down your favorite childhood dessert- I hope mine makes a debut on their menu. The peaches and cream were delicious. And I love how they have a bit of historical info. on each dessert dish. The drinks were also steller- I had a spicy peach champagne. It was inventive and the perfect balance of sweet and hrat. I am so glad that this establishment is only a stones throw away.
author: Allie P.

description:
Yum! What a wonderful restaurant!
I really have nothing but good things to say about Stones Throw.

FOOD:
- Puffed potato and eggs ($8): With cauliflower mousse, chives, and crispy chicken skin. I know this was just a starter/snack, but this was SO GOOD. It came with about four puffed potatoes served in a dish of cauliflower mousse, but I honestly could have eaten about then of those little magical potato puff creations and still be craving more. The potatoes are perfectly fluffy and the crispy chicken skin adds just the right amount of crunch and texture.

- Duck Liver Mousse ($10): With walnut genoise, beet gelee, apples, and mustard greens. If you are a fan of duck liver mousse, you are going to loveeee the duck liver mousse at Stones Throw-- super creamy and rich.

- Squid Ink Conchiglie ($17): With spicy capers, calms, mussels, shrimp, and tender greens. The conchiglie pasta looked more like fusilli pasta to me, but that didn't detract in the slightest from how much I enjoyed this dish. The flavor was spot on. My only complaint would be that I wish that the portion size was bigger.

- American Wagyu Flank Steak ($29): With Beet spatzle, horseradish-chermoula, mushrooms, and caramelized onions. Super savory and tender. Another dish where I wish the portion size was bigger, but it was so so good! The steak was perfectly tender and quite savory. 

- Grasshopper dessert with chocolate lava, mint, and pretzel toffee ($9): I'm not normally a dessert person, but this was quite refreshing. The pretzel toffee was a nice addition.

The thing I like most about dessert at Stones Throw though is that they really encourage you to "participate" in creating their dessert menu. You have the option of writing own your favorite childhood dessert, and if they pick your selection as their inspiration for a new dessert, then you're invited back to Stones Throw to try the dessert creation for free!

Ambiance was great, server was wonderful. Make a reservation if you can!

tl;dr: I am obsessed with Stones Throw. The food was sooooo good! I just wish that the portion sizes were larger so I could enjoy more of the deliciousness they serve here.
author: Lillian Z.

description:
Food is amazing and atmosphere laid back and cool. The place is pretty pricy for what you get though!

As I said the food was great but the portions are tiny, so tiny that after we left and went to a wine bar later in evening we ordered snacks as we were peckish! We had the pate and they gave us 3 tiny pieces of toast that were not enough to spread the small portion on as they were slithers. We aske for bread which came one piece cut into two and were charged $3 for that! My wife had the delicious sea bass and I had the steak all super but at the risk of being repetitive small plates.

The worst of it was the aweful waitress who was condescending and unfriendly to the point of making us feel like we did not belong!
author: Mark J.

description:
The food:
Puffy potatoes: 5/5 so good!! the potato balls were light and fluffy, and the sauce had a ton of flavor
Squid Ink Pasta Shell: 5/5 very flavorful. The sauce was rich and the capers complimented the sauce perfectly
Green pea risotto: 4/5 interesting dish, I've never had green risotto before! The dish tasted very fresh and the toasted nuts were a nice touch. I'm just not the biggest fan of risotto in general and this one didn't win me over, but was still quite tasty 
Steak: 4/5 your average joe steak. Plating was on point tho. And the sauce was good and potatoes + brocollini a nice touch 
Campanelle Pasta: 5/5 super flavorful! the pasta was well cooked and the sauce was really tasty 
Peanut butter and Jelly Donuts: 5/5 so good!! it reminded me of beignets. The peanut butter they used was super creamy and fluffy 

The ambiance:
Saw good mix of people dressed casually and more nicely. Not too loud, good for date night. Also saw some groups of 8ish so seems like they can accommodate larger parties as well. Service was great and everyone was super friendly
author: Sijia Z.

description:
A absolute bargain for the price point, especially in SF. Made a reservation on a Sunday for six people around noon and were happily seated immediately. Their brunch food menu is on the smaller side - only about a dozen choices - but it's nice that they have smaller plates ("snacks" priced around $8) as well as larger brunch classics. 

We ordered a plate of the Peach Bellini doughnuts for the table to start. They were delightful - a little less than tennis ball size, coated with sugar and laced with a peachy glaze. For my main course, I got the puffed potato and egg since I wasn't too hungry. It was perfectly portioned, with four balls of whipped potato goodness with a soft-boiled egg yolk inside, topped with plenty of bacon bits + chive and backed by a luscious aioli underneath. It was large enough to keep me satisfied and again - amazing at the price point.

The only "expensive" thing here for me was the coffee, which came out to $4 for a fairly average cup of joe. Otherwise, everything was excellent.
author: Andrew H.

description: Great food and service. Really a great place to take friends and visitors for an awesome dinner.
author: Felix B.

description:
The food was slightly pricey but delicious. We were served quickly, our waitress was very attentive and patient. 

You can come here for a romantic lunch or on a date- either way the atmosphere was great!

I strongly urge you to make a reservation as they get busier later in the evening. Also, Uber/ Lyft or carpool b/c parking is terrible
author: Nae F.

description:
I feel like this place is a hidden gem (no one seems to bring it up when talking about great San Francisco restaurants). I originally found it because I'm a huge fan of Trestle (also owned by them). I LOVE Trestle, and I LOVE this place, too. We've been to this place twice now and both times have been overly impressed by the service and the food. The menu is simple (like Trestle), and I'm guessing it changes often (the desserts definitely do). Great wine selection (no hard liquor).

One of the best parts about Stones Throw is their unique desserts all based on childhood favorites. The first time we were there we were asked to write down our favorite childhood dessert to be given to the chef and told if the dessert was fixed we would get to come back for free. Not sure if they still do that, though, because we weren't asked to do so on our most recent visit. Either way, great desserts (and I'm not even much of a dessert fan)!
author: Derrick S.

description:
Ok, this is currently my new favorite restaurant. Service was amazing - loved our waitress and Ryan, the owner.

We started off with the puffed potato and eggs w/crispy chicken skin? Ugh, it was SO good! So this set the stage for the rest of the meal, I was super excited for some reason. Next we had the shrimp ceviche, which was also on point, the perfect amount of tang and spice. Next up was the squid ink conchiglie w/clams, mussels, and squid... We normally don't order squid ink, but thank god we did cause it was AMAZING. The greens, shellfish, and pasta were perfect together.. I'm salivating thinking about it haha. Then we had the steak which was also delicious! And topped off the meal with the peanut butter and jelly donuts -- seriously, order them. They're light and fluffy, not too sweet so you don't feel guilty afterwards! :) We'll be back soon!!
author: Kim I.

description:
Best squid ink pasta I've ever had. The spices that went into the dish all complimented each other. I was very disappointed in the tiny proportion that my $20 dinner entree came out with. The pasta was delicious but the food was too little. They plated it very nicely to make it seem like a lot of food, but in all honesty, there were probably 20 pieces of pasta and 15 pieces of tiny seafood in there. I would recommend this dish based on the taste. There is a small kick to the pasta! Highly recommend it if you can get over the color. My boyfriend refused to eat it at first but gave in and fell in love with the dish. WE ended up getting a second plate because we just needed more of this perfection in our lives. 

It was quite packed when we left so be sure to make reservations! Be sure to try the Squid ink pasta! You won't regret it! 

Highly recommend this place!
author: Shannon H.

description:
Family style brunch here = one of the best kept secrets in SF

1. YOU CAN MAKE RESERVATIONS?! Granted, the family style brunch is for 6 or more. Table for 6 at 11:30 on a Sunday? check
2. YOU GET TO TRY HELLA FOOD. All their best plates, basically. We were served 2 of everything so that each plate was split between 3 people. Some of their snacks (the beignets omg), and some of the main dishes (hellooooo waffle). We had 1 vegetarian at the table and it was no problem for them to accommodate her.
3. The food is delicious! By the end of the meal we were more than full. And the atmosphere is really cute. Russian hill is so quaint in the morning.
4. Um. $25 per person? What? Are you sure?

I hear big things about the burger here, and will definitely be back for dinner. Highly recommended!
author: Steph D.

description: Lucky find. Saw it from the trolley car and made a point to check it out. You will not be disappointed. Beer and wine list is exceptional, staff are super friendly and look to enhance your visit with pleasant table side manor. Halibut was fabulous. Highly recommended. Side note: Spruce Tip Ale is quite possibly the best beer I've ever had.
author: Dave F.

description:
Ok I know I might have already thrown the "this is my favorite restaurant in SF hands down" once but THIS tops them all. I can't even begin to describe how amazing the food to the service to the decor is.

I've had the pleasure of dining here twice. Once because my friend is related to the head chef, the second time with my co-workers as a holiday celebration. Both times were marvelous.

You know the food is good when everyone's plate is wiped clean just moments after appetizers are placed on the table. The Duck Pate & Mousse, clearly the winner that we had to get another order. This was a light sweet and savory dish with complimenting soft pretzel. I felt like the mustard seeds added a great crunch. The Puffed Potato & Eggs and Crispy Soft Shell Crab were marvelous as well. The Braised Tomato with Bread was ok in comparison.

On to main courses. The Squid Ink Pasta is definitely my favorite go to!

For drinks I got the Pineapple Express, a delicious cocktail that makes you question whether it has any alcohol at all.

Definitely would come back.
author: Kathy L.

description:
Hm - not as great as i remembered it to be.

Food: got the same thing i from the first review i wrote. pate was ok. puffed potatoes were great. Squid ink pasta was verrryyy disappointing. It was soooo salty. Almost inedible. We also got the octopus which was just OK too.
author: Laura D.

description:
Definitely enjoyed my first visit to ST. The staff was friendly and provided some great recommendations. I'd highly recommend setting up a reservation, because even right at the 11am opening slot for brunch, the place was packed!

Appetizers: We shared a few doughnuts (~$8 for an order of 4) and I actually thought this was the best part of the meal! I'd save an order for dessert on my next visit. We also had an order of the puffed potato (~$8), but I didn't care for these too much.

Entree: I ordered the Duck Hash Confit (~$15), which came with brussel sprouts, a pair of poached eggs, and some toast. It was good but not great.

Drinks: Our group also had an order of mimosas and some rose in a Porron (this one was pretty neat because the staff emphatically showed our group how to drink from the container). 

Overall, I thought the food was good quality but a bit overpriced for the quantity. Such is life in SF, I suppose :)

Last note - appreciated them having a place to store a few bags since my fiancee and I were traveling home after brunch!
author: Garrett O.

description: The food is incredible here! The trout and pork are personal favorites (many of the dishes are beef-based and I don't eat beef so I can't speak on the burger or steak). The endive salad is scrumptious! They offer a ton of beer options! We went on Sunday for a post-bridal shower dinner to celebrate the bride and groom and they brought us 8 free peanut butter beignets!!! So delicious. Unfortunately, they're often out of several beer options... otherwise great service, ambiance, and food!
author: Zinia G.

description:
Had dinner here last night and the overall experience was excellent!

Food was quite good and very good value, for $55/person we had so much food we could barely finish. The service was outstanding and the wine list is incredible. The pricing on bottles is also incredible with many bottles being marked up less $20 and some being sold at basically retail price! e.g. Corison 2014 for $110.

Food - 4 stars
Staff/Service - 5 stars
Wine List/Pricing - 5 stars
author: Michael T.

description: We love this restaurant!!!  My pics are of empty plates because it's that good. Pasta with short rib ragu, scallops, mushroom risotto all delish. Had a vegan friend that they happily accommodated. Manger to get dessert photos. Highly recommend!!
author: Elizabeth S.

description: So I really would put it at 3 1/2 stars.  We were sat right away with reservations.  The decor is ok a little too cafeteria style for my taste and they need to do something about the noise. We did a good deal of screaming across the table.  The food is good.  The chef seems to want a "new" take on all foods, onion soup, burrata, Apple pie,  gratin...  these are some hits some misses but the flavors are there you just need to be open to this idea. Service started slow.  Took them a while to get our drinks but then picked up and did well after that.  Would I do it more than once probably not as at that price point there are other better restaurants but still worth the once.
author: Stevie H.

description:
Had a dinner tasting here for a wedding celebration for the bride-to-be.

The interior of the place was cute, dimly lit and filled with happy diners from couples, groups of friends to even families. Since we had a reservation, we were promptly taken to our table in the back and was served water as we waited for some of the rest of our party to arrive.

Our menu was quite extensive and surely, I wish I had three hands so I could've taken photos of each dish, eat and drink with the others. 

Snacks: 
Duck Pate & Mousse with Cornichons and French's mustard served with soft pretzels - You can't go wrong with pate and carbs. The richness of the pate was through with the crunchy and acidic mustard. Major yum!

Smoked Salmon Spread with bread - I thought the smoked salmon was great, super creamy and salmony without being too "fishy". It's possible. The bread was on the tougher side and definitely needed to be served with more bread as the portions left you with more spread than bread.

Puffed Potato & Egg - I don't know what it is about this but it is all about comfort. The puffed potato with rich egg yolk was great with the cauliflower mousse. The chives brighten up the richness and the texture of crispy chicken skin was a great contrast to the soft texture.

Starters:
Escarole Salad with truffle pecorino and Asian pear - was a simple, yet refreshing way to start prior to starting our main dishes. Fresh, light, lovely!

Mains:
Crispy-skinned trout with Celery Root and Roasted Brussels Sprouts - Probably one of my favorite dishes that came out. The trout came out perfectly cooked, lovely crispy skin, succulent flesh, and the celery root puree was smooth but rich to create a more rich and filling accompaniment to the fish.

Squid Ink conchiglie pasta - I would have liked this if the sauce was a little less salty. I felt that the pasta texture was beautiful and not tough. I did not find a distinct squid ink flavor, but the color was impactful. The only downside was it was way too salty for my taste.

Braised Beef Shortrib - really tender beef, comes with potato gratin. Definitely a well rounded and rich plate, but definitely satisfying.

Desserts (chef's choice):

PB & J Donuts - good, but not amazing. These donuts are more like beignets with the fillings of peanut butter and jelly on the side. Don't get me wrong, fried dough is delicious!

Tiramisu - little-cubed lady fingers soaked in espresso and alcohol (I'm guessing, rum?) topped with white chocolate twirls, dollops of coffee cream and vanilla ice cream quenelle on top.

Chocolate Tacos - these are a fun retro throwback, but with Stone's Throw's twist. Little chocolate tacos filled with vanilla ice cream and served with chocolate drops, toffee brittle, apple slices and jelly

The following are just a few items, I thought would be worth mentioning. Although, we had tasted a lot more, but were not entirely memorable. The only con is that although we had two of each item, it seemed a bit difficult for every person to have a bit of the dish as they were small in portion. It's understood as it is a tasting, but a little on the small side in terms of portions.

Service was phenomenal considering it was a full house. The servers were so attentive and informative about all the dishes. We also had a few allergy and dietary restrictions in our party and they were really great at providing dishes that everyone could eat without issue. Great little place, decent pricing for a tasting with many dishes and amazing service!
author: Janet N.

description:
What a great little neighborhood spot. We decided to split a bunch of starters and were not disappointed at all. They were also served in the perfect order, building upon the flavors. Cool decor and atmosphere, kind of forage-y. Good for a small group of friends or a nice date night.

Dishes: 

Crudo of steelhead trout - Light and fresh with the perfect amount of crunch and acid on top.

Citrus poached shrimp - Wow! Whatever is in the butternut squash purée should be bottled and sold. Each layer of this dish just added more, from the soft purée to the crunch of the dried prosciutto. Perfect bite on the lavash. A must-order.

Duck liver mousse - I never pass this up when it's on a menu and glad I didn't here either. Creamy and smooth, it was served on a cake-type base rather than with bread or crackers. The gelee on top added the perfect amount of sweetness.

Squid ink pasta - Yum! I mean, creamy, salty, and acidic. The flavors don't get much better. The seafood was cooked perfectly - esp the super meaty shrimp. (Wish there was more of course!) And the pasta was al dente and hearty without being too dense. 

Bonus dessert - pbj donuts. Somewhere between a donut, cake, and a beignet - awesome bite with the chocolates, peanut butter, and jelly all together. So light, yet so flavorful.

Great beer list! Smaller wine by the glass list. We sat at the bar, and our bartender/server was awesome! So nice and knowledgable, made sure we were taken care of and never had an empty water glass. 

5+ for flavor, creativity, and all around deliciousness. Pricing is interesting as some things seem nicely priced (mousse, shrimp), yet some things seemed overpriced. Can't speak for the mains. Either way, looking forward to going back. Toughest thing will be deciding whether to order the same things or try new ones.
author: Rebecca S.

description:
Great food and great service.  I tried:
- Shrimp appetizer (4.5/5) - Great combination of flavors and textures between the shrimp, prosciutto, sauce, and cracker.
- Squid ink pasta (4/5) - Nice seafood flavor and great texture from the pasta, but a little over-salted.
- Bavette steak (4.5/5) - Perfectly tender meat, that mixes just right with the mushrooms and chermoula sauce.  Delicious spaetzle with crispy exterior.
- Steelhead trout - Only had a single bite off my girlfriend's plate.
- "Fudgesicle" dessert (4/5) - Really chocolatey ice cream well paired with kiwi and sesame cake.

Although there were only four beers on tap, there was a whole page of available bottles.  For two people, it was ~$140 after tax and tip.  Really great dining experience, definitely makes my top ten favorites in SF.
author: Simon L.

description:
3.5 stars for food, rounding up for service.  I think my expectations got the better of me.

I've seen Stones Throw on Yelp so many times, I already knew a lot of the things I wanted to order before I walked in the door.  Potato puffs sound like they're never going to be a bad idea, but they were a bit one-note to me.  Not enough crispiness in the dish to counter the rich egg yolk and potato.  Squid ink pasta and kurobuta pork chop were solid, but almost on the border of being too flavorful?  There's just a lot going on in all of the dishes, which make them fun to eat once but never has you craving them again.

I wanted more of an intense peanut butter flavor in the PB&J donuts, all in all it was too sweet of a dish for me.  The beignets are pillow soft though, without the liberal coating of sugar they must be divine.  

Tips and Tricks
-Made a reservation the day before and were promptly seated
-Drove around for forever looking for street parking but managed to find a spot around Larkin and FIlbert
-Bring your friend with that fancy ring light, the low lighting makes it hard to take nice pictures
author: Jessica L.

description:
I have been here twice for dinner, and another time for brunch. Consistently fresh, high service level, and beautiful ambiance. Stones Throw is comfort at it's best with seasonally fresh menu.

Parking is a hassle. I always take a car or taxi here. 

Note: they don't have cocktails, but they have a great breadth of wine and beer.
author: Amy O.

description: Everything here was great!  The service exceptional.  There were four people serving our table at various times. So kind, so professional, so quick!   The food was the best I've had in a long time.  Pasta with sugo sauce was delish!  Just the right amount of balance between meat, sauce and perfectly done pasta.  We really enjoyed our experience and will definitely return.
author: Linda V.

description:
As pleasant and delicious as a Russian Hill gem should be. Our server was delightful...affable, easygoing and helpful with our selections. The chef was accommodating to vegan requests.
The spring pea risotto had a wonderful texture, perfectly seasoned and just the right dish for a SF summer after-work evening. 
The miso in the hamachi crudo was spot on.
author: A K.

description:
My first time visiting Stones Throw (ST) was back in Sept 2016. Ever since that visit, I've dreamed of coming back for the squid ink pasta, which felt like I put heaven in my mouth. I've compared every single restaurant I've been to as "not as good," using ST as the ultimate standard. 

Fast forward nearly 1.5 years now, my parents were in town visiting and I finally got my opportunity take my parents to my favorite restaurant! Clearly, this is no longer the case. Besides the shameless teeny tiny portions for the price, the service we received on our second visit was demeaning, leaving a bad taste in my mouth regardless of how the food was.

Our waitress was Dawn. Dawn answered every single one of my questions with a judgmental look that made me feel very uncomfortable, and a tone of voice with choice was words that was extremely rude. For example, I asked her to explain what was the difference bet hamachi crudo and another starter. She replied, "well hamachi is a fish, and that is not." ....did I look that stupid? I wanted to know how the dish was created and how they differed since the ingredients sounded similar. I tried to ask again and she was very hasty and arrogant in her tone of voice. I felt belittled and ashamed for even asking any questions. 

Later on during our meal, she came over and almost purposely asked if this was our first time here, if we are from here, if we live around this area. Very specific questions as if trying to point us out that we are foreign to here and don't know anything about food. Needless to say, ST is no longer my favorite restaurant! Sad since it left an epic impression the first time.
author: Acacia O.

description: One of our go-to spots in the neighborhood. Good for everything - date night, catching up with friends, small work dinners. Food is delicious and beautifully plated. All of our servers have been friendly, professional and knowledgeable. Beer and wine only. Recommend making reservations.
author: Sarina Y.

description:
One of the BEST dining experiences I've ever had. I base most of my restaurant reviews on the food presentation and flavor alone because honestly, good service is hard to find and if you get it, you have to pay an arm and a leg for it. But the servers at this place were so pleasant and efficient that the most memorable part of the meal, for once, was the service. We had two servers to our table who made great recommendations about the food and drinks. They constantly cleared our table and brought new silverware with each beautifully prepared dish. I've paid a lot more for mediocre food and poor service so this place is now on my top 10 restaurant experiences. 

Drinks: Chupacabra & Blonde Ale

Food: Fondue & Brussels Sprouts, Split Pea Soup, Pasta, Burger & tatter tots

Extensive Beer & Wine list
author: Mitzi G.

description: the food was good. ambiance a little cold but I think that's just bc the waitress was not very warm. She seemed rushed and annoyed. Not sure why. We had a Rez and it wasn't the end of the night. We are more cocktail people so the fact it was only beer & wine also wasn't a huge hit for us. I enjoyed it but doubt I'll go back.
author: Jillian S.

description:
With a friend in town I finally had the excuse I was looking for and we walked over to Powell to start with oysters, and catch a cable car.  

The cable cars were the weak link of the evening.

The decor is sparse---I've walked past it frequently and it's much emptier in appearance than it would seem through the window.  The menu isn't much more robust, until you turn to the beer list---which could almost call for one to eat the food on small plates just to work your way down to a beer you really want.  I didn't look at the wine list but asked for a nice big cab and we got two glasses of just that (I didn't even ask what it was) and a nice one too.

We started with the chicken liver pate and squid ink conchiglie and then both of us had the Bavette Steak.  I make a nice chicken liver pate at home, this was much better---the lovely muskiness of the liver but softer and quieter.  We had to ask for more bread on which to spread it as it couldn't be wasted.  The conchiglie was very good, black spirals of pasta in a dark creamy sauce with what was said to be clams, mussels and shrimp but I don't really remember any of that, just the sharp rich flavor of the clams and mussels, and the pasta.

Which brings us to the Bavette Steak, or flap meat.  Yes, another rendering of the lesser cuts of the cow which are as prevalent on menus as battleship gray is on all the buildings.  It was served with a pungent Moroccan chermoula sauce more traditionally reserved for fish and pan seared vegetables all of which came together delightfully.  

We finished with the Fudgesicle (the popsicle version apparently having been invented in San Francisco).  Oddly enough, the entire description of this dish is devoted to the history of the popsicle, and you have to go on the list of ingredients under the name: Kiwi compote; coconut jam; black sesame.  It seemed more like a mini cookie layer cake in macaron drag than anything remotely popsicle or fudgesicle, and of everything on the menu, this came closest to disappointment----had the cable car service not already taken that position.

Sadly, no tawny port, only ruby, and with that we finished.

I'd go back although with the limited selection there isn't a lot of rush to do so.
author: Paul T.

description:
3.5 stars

Beautiful ambiance. Came here for brunch and food was just meh. The appetizers (puffed potato and smoked trout mousse) were the highlights compared to my entree (veggie scramble). My toast came completely burnt to the point that it was inedible. It was also very heavy on potatoes which was a bit unexpected. We ordered rose for the table, which was provided in a beautiful decanter looking carafe. Coffee was good.
author: Yin H.

description:
The food here is quite good and I love the extensive beer list but if you are ordering IPA's in cans and bottles, I would double check the freshness of said beers. While there is no expiration date, I (like many others) do prefer super fresh beers ideally weeks if not a month after bottled or canned. Last time I came here I had an IPA several months old so now I stick to the IPA's on tap, bottled beers that age better or I just stick with water. 

When ordering food, they do not allow you to order a snack or appetizer without putting in your whole order in first - the reason provided was to optimize the flow and experience of the meal. Just an FYI in case you arrive starving and are unable to order anything ahead of time. With that said, the food did arrive fairly quickly so I will give them that.

As for the bill, I did notice they provide suggested tips amount of 15%, 18% and 20% which is helpful for diners but these totals are based on top of fees and taxes and not the sub-total like most other restaurants. I am not a fan of this approach even though I do my own calculations but for the rest of people who gloss over this small detail, just a head sup.

Overall I would give this a 3.5 stars based
author: E E.

description:
Brunch was pretty decent here. I tried the burger and it was seasoned well and very flavorful. The fries were a little dry but he burger made up for it. I'd come back if I was in the area.

Reservations are recommended. It gets busy til about 2pm.

The ambience is nice, a little noisy but we were in the back corner so it was somewhat more private than he middle of the restaurant.

 Bathrooms are clean and nice.

All in all a good experience.
author: Jess A.

description:
We tried dinner and brunch here.  Between the two options, we preferred the brunch.  

For brunch, we tried:
1. Bottle of mimosa your way
2. Oysters on the half shell*
3. Smoked salmon mousse*
4. Doughnuts
5. Monkey bread
6. Chili verde braised pork belly
7. Soft scrambled*
8. Duck confit hash*

* Table favorites.  

Both times we had decent service.
author: Kayla N.

description: Sat at the bar for drinks and dinner. Our bartender was very personable and attentive! Great wines and enjoyed the starters we ordered. I appreciated the opportunity to try a few wines that we new to me. The burger comes with the best tater tots! Would recommend for a nice atmosphere and good food!
author: Jessica L.

description:
Bird lovers: eat here!

The aesthetic of Stones Throw is awesome, and really nods to birds. It's a cozy place that you'd like to spend time on appetizers and their fun beer and cocktail list.

The food at Stones Throw is per the 3 stars. "Snacks" are bird food-sized portions (a small scoop of burrata over chives or a calamari dish for one). Portions for dinner are more filling, but definitely nothing to write home about. My Dad was impressed with the trout and I was surprised by the short rib gnocchi, although I wished for more gnocchi (meat-pasta ratio was a little off). The waiter suggested there was ricotta in the gnocchi, but I never tasted it. Other dish, the bolognese (technically a "starter") was a unique try at bolognese and tasted really fishy.

Staff was incredibly friendly (OpenTable was finicky last night and our 8:15 reservation popped up as 8:30). They seemed to be offering champagne to those with long waits, and had a clever little dessert menu  to keep the experience interesting.

I'd return to Stones Throw for drinks at the bar, but I'd avoid dinner until they switch up their menu a bit.
author: Kerry G.

description: Delicious!!! First time at this restaurant. Was a little bit of a cab ride from where we live in SOMA but well worth the ride. Pretty busy little corner with what appeared to be some great restaurants. The food here is delicious and presentation is entertaining. The bar is only beer and wine but they make specialty cocktails that they have created and they are very tasty!
author: Genia P.

description: The food was exceptional! Very delicious and unique. Service good as well. We made a reservation so didn't have to wait. But the restaurant was indeed packed. Loved scallops, very fresh. Only downside is... it was very expensive. But worth trying once in a while.
author: Amanda K.

description:
We had dinner here recently. Overall it was good, but for the price I think there are better places to go. Service was attentive, but slightly condescending. Ambiance was comfortable - it's good for a date or with friends but wouldn't call it special occasion atmosphere.

We had the calamari snack, potato puffs, squid ink pasta, steak, halibut, eggplant risotto and several desserts. Overall the flavor was good on everything. But it was all served kind of lukewarm. On some dishes that is ok, but on others, such as the halibut and potato puffs, it was dissatisfying. The portions are tiny and I wish the waiter had warned us since we were sharing among 6 people. When they arrived it made me feel worried that we weren't going to have enough food. There was really only enough to share with each person getting a mouthful or 2. So I think this made me feel uneasy and not enjoy the meal as much as I hoped. The entrees are on the small side for an entree. The potato puffs are decent size for the price, but the other "snacks" are really tiny. 

The good thing is that the food all looks very pretty and interesting. And it did taste good but didn't blow me away.
author: linky w.

description:
What a spectacular experience. 
What the menu lacks in size it makes up for in quality & execution. Highlights for the culinary program was the whole menu but the pastas and potato appetizer are a must have. Beverage team not only has an amazing sense of humor but the approach to the design and engineering is ingenious and the offerings thoughtful with great value. 
Can't wait to visit again.
author: Gary FX L.

description:
My best friend generously gifted me with a $100 gift certificate to this restaurant, so we came here with a party of 4 for Sunday brunch. The inside of the restaurant is quite large, with high ceilings and a lot of tables. We ordered the following:

Smoked salmon mousse with bagel chips, creme fraiche, and scallions ($8): this starter was quite tasty. The salmon mousse was light and airy, and had some subtle flavors (a little spicy, a little sour, not too fishy), and came with deliciously seasoned and buttered crispy bagel chips.
Strawberry shortcake doughnuts with shortcake crumble, rhubarb jam, and vanilla cream ($8): these were delicious! The doughnuts were hot and just out of the fryer, and packed on the inside with tart rhubarb jam and dusted on the outside with sugar. I also really liked the vanilla cream on the side.
The burger ($16): the burger was large and filling. The meat was juicy and while it didn't have the the usual accompaniments (lettuce, tomato, onion), if had some sort of slaw and mayo-based dressing that was quite delicious. The tater tots were stuffed with bacon and cheese and came with a ranch dressing. Definitely not healthy, but tasty!
Pastrami hash with shishito peppers, corn, poached eggs, and mustard creme fraiche ($17): the hash was very tasty. It came with two poached eggs which had runny yolk (just the way I like them), and the hash itself wasn't too greasy, although it was a little watery.

Overall we had a good time, even though the power went out in the middle of our meal. I thought the price was a bit expensive for the amount of food, but the food itself was quite good.
author: Amy C.

description:
This is one of my favorite spots to take visitors for a nice dinner. The food is excellent, it's tucked away in a beautiful little neighborhood, and the vibe is hip yet it's not impossible to get a reservation on short notice.

Fun little gimmick: they solicit diners at the end of the meal to share their favorite childhood desserts. If they select yours ... I'm not sure what will happen, but it's fun to imagine your favorite dessert getting dressed up all upscale-like!
author: Greg P.

description:
I arranged for Stones Throw to be my first stop on a night of bookmark hopping. By the end of our time here my only lament was not having the time to have a full coursed meal. 

The ambiance is a winner. Looking at the prices on the menu prior to my visit, I expected average service. Surprisingly, the level of attention to detail was above anything I would of imagined. Constant visits, clean utensils and glasses after dishes and drinks, they own it.

Puffed potato and eggs...the cauliflower mouse and chicken skin with the texture of the potato came lightly. The taste was gentle and rich. 4.5/5

Spicy Capers, Clams, Calamari, Shrimp...in the squid ink pasta. I thought twice about this one as squid ink pasta is a favorite of mine and well disappointments are worse when it's over something you love. But the combination of flavors on paper were to much to say no to. Trust me, the tastes depth was more consistent than Chris Mullin's buzz cut. 4.75/5

Our drinks were ciders. Troy and another one from the central valley of California. Both which were on the farmhouse end of the tasting scale, good ones to try if you appreciate the real stuff. They had a canned cider that I tasted as well, for the lighter drinkers. Thanks for staying away from the angry orchards and brooks, very heartwarming. 

In a city full of restaurant Goliaths. a Stones Throw gets it done. The service, the food, even the ciders they menu serve purpose.
author: Javier J.

description:
All I can say is "WOW"! This place was soooo good. I've had it bookmarked for awhile because it was recommended to me by Emma H., and now I can see why she raved about it. A couple friends and I met for a 6:45 reservation and it didn't get crowded until around 7:30/8. One person from our party was running 20+ minutes late, but none of the staff seemed to mind which was nice. I never felt rushed.

I ordered a pilsner to start and it was really good. Their beer list is extensive, as is the wine list, and I would love to come back with the hubby and order a bottle with dinner. We ended up ordering one snack (the duck pate and mouse), and one appetizer (the grilled octopus).  The former was delicious!! I've never had duck pate and was a little nervous to try it, but it basically tasted like creamy mustard because of the mustard seeds, which was amazing with the pretzels. Would definitely order this again, but I also want to try the egg puffs.  The octopus was solid and the fresh fruit on the plate complimented it well. It was super tender too. 

For my main I had the gnudi and am seriously still fantasizing about it today! It was so light and fluffy and, just, perfect. My only complaint is I wish there was more. I seriously think I could have eaten two plates, and that's saying something because I typically eat like a bird. I can't see myself ordering any other entrée next time.

The service was great and really friendly. The kitchen was a little backed up, but that's understandable since it was packed. Can't wait to come back and have already recommended it to a couple people.
author: Steph L.

description: I love this place. The food is amazing and you don't need anything else.  Braised Short Rib, Steak, wow.
author: Michael S.

description:
Ambiance:

The restaurant was quaint, and trendy. I went on Easter Sunday and the place was packed! I love to people watch and sometimes even ear hustle a little so the noise level was not a problem.  

Service: 

I loved the staffs professionalism, and really appreciated their genuine kindness. Very welcoming. 

Food: 

We ordered the pastrami hash, and the potato puffs. The pastrami was ok nothing memorable but it got the job done, a solid 3. The potato puffs are a popular item and we were looking forward to trying them, but disappointed, they were almost too salty to enjoy. Bummer :( not in a rush to go back but wouldn't turn it away. The couple next to us ordered something that looked amazing
author: Jesus L.

description:
An upscale bistro in Russian Hill, Stones Throw tries to occupy a spot on the restaurant spectrum that's not quite fine dining, yet is classy enough to rise above your run-of-the-mill neighborhood joint. Bite-sized plates run $8 each, for example, with starters going for $12-18 each and entrees ranging from $25-30 each.

A meaty duo of beef ribeye and braised shortrib, accompanied with Yukon Gold potatoes, charred cabbage, spring onion, and chimichurri, was quite decent, although not quite enough to satisfy an appetite I'd worked up - so I went right ahead and ordered some blackberry cobbler. The food was all certainly well-prepared and by no means bad, though.

I think the real strong point of the establishment is its extensive beer and wine menus. There are at least 50 beers available, spanning many styles and crisscrossing the globe. Similarly, the wine list exceeds 50 and is somewhat more skewed towards local offerings, yet has a fair number of Old World names.

It's certainly a sophisticated venue for a date, or for an upscale meal alongside well-chosen beer or wine offerings. Not a bad place to try out if you're in the neighborhood.
author: Vincent L.

description:
The hostess was kind enough to accommodate us during peak time without a reservation. Had a couple of dishes to share: 


Puffed potato and egg (cauliflower mousse and bacon)- simple dish, not something I'd try again. Portion was a bit small. Consistency was puréed. 

Hawaiian sweet roll bread pudding- sweet, ingredients were there it just wasn't executed like a traditional bread pudding. It lacked eggs and consistency was like a cheesecake.

Pancake- fluffy and soft. A plus on the real maple syrup that came standard w it. 

Burger- buns were toasted nicely, the patty juicy and flavorful. The tater tots were a nice change to your regular fries. 

The brunch menu needed more veggie options.
author: Kai A.

description:
THE BURGER HERE IS LIKE HOW YOU WOULD EAT A KRABBY PATTY IN A SPONGEBOB SCENE.
It was the perfect burger I ever had.. 
I think I got sweet potato fries or regular. 
It was very crispy and yummy. 
I feel like they are known for their burgers as well. 
FOR SURE GET IT AND NO REGRETS.
author: Julia D.

description:
Dined here a few days ago for the first time. I thought the service was great, extremely friendly and attentive staff. The food was good enough that I would come back. There were a few standouts and a few misses.

What we ordered:
- Shrimp Ceviche: nothing that stand outs with this dish. Pretty average and I've definitely had better ceviche elsewhere. I would pass
+ Puffed Potato & Eggs: this was a really good snack. the little balls were delicious and perfect to share.
- Chicken Liver Mousse: the mousse was good but the jam on top was way too sweet. would have preferred it with the jam on the side so we could add it ourselves if we wanted. the rye crisps were nice and our waiter gave us more without us needing to ask :)
++ Melon & Cucumber Salad: we really liked this dish! so much that we wished we ordered two to share. super refreshing and tasty dish as a starter.
++ Squid Ink Pasta: oh man, this dish doesn't look like much but it was SO delicious and flavorful. This is one of their signature dishes and definitely recommend.
- Ricotta Ravioli: this dish was okay. nothing that stands out, maybe because the squid ink pasta was just that good and overshadowed it.
-- Striped Bass: wow this main was the worst dish of the night. everyone agreed that there was an incredibly strong fishy flavor that ruined the entire dish. It was so bad that I did tell the waiter in case they were serving bad fish. They were very polite with the feedback and ended up comping us one of our desserts.
+ Seared Wagyu: this main was good. perfectly cooked medium rare and super flavorful. 

We saw other people order the burger w/ tater tots so I would try that dish next time. We asked if we could just get a side of tater tots but unfortunately they couldn't make extra so that was a bummer.

Dessert:
+ Peaches & Cream: this was good! we almost licked the entire glass clean haha
+ Peanut Butter & Jelly Donuts: this was also good! it comes out like puff pastries and you dip it into the PB&J sauce on the side of the plate

Overall I would recommend this place as a casual night out since reservations were easy to get and the vibe was good. The service is why I'd rate it 4 stars instead of 3.
author: Kathy L.

description:
Our server was very nice. She didn't suggest any stand outs on the menu, but when I asked about the coffee cake, she did say it was one of her favorites. She did ask if we had any food dislikes or allergies.

We ordered: Coffee Cake - it was deconstructed with jam and crunchy streusel topping. Then there was a white sauce drizzled over the cake. It was super good....like crazy good.

Cheeseburger with tater tots - the hamburger was very good, good flavor and the cheese was totally melted over the entire burger. The tots were not my favorite, and we thought they were more like hushpuppies versus tots. Maybe next time I'd substitute for a side salad? Not sure they do substitutions.

Hash - this was so good, two eggs on the top, over easy and the hash underneath. Very favorful, not too much potato (can't stand that), but the right amount. The meat was seasoned a little spicy, quite nice.

Seating was on the tight/close side, thinking more NYC style, so the issue becomes that people are always trying to talk over everyone else. Then, it can become a general shout-fest. When exiting the bench seat, it was difficult to squeeze in between the tables, it was that close.

Overall, I have to say the service was very friendly and I didn't feel rushed even though people were waiting inside and outside. Reservations HIGHLY recommended, but I would try to get there when they first open for brunch.
author: Terry L.

description:
The service was great as well as the wine (littoria pinot) but the food was just not that good.  Nothing about portion size like all the other reviews, just really not that great tasting of food.  We got everything people rave about (squid ink, potato puffs) and nothing even came close to being as good as the bottle of wine.

Go for the wine.
author: Neil A.

description:
Ahhhhhhh - this is now my favorite restaurant in SF.... or at least in Russian Hill. Granted it has a lot of competition. But it's so good... and so.... what's the word... out of the ordinary and extraordinary.... at the same time... yeah I said it....and no it's not the same thing. 

Didn't have reservations but the manager was kind enough to loan us a table for a few hours ( I say that because it was adorable how he said... "we can seat you...but I might need the table back at 8pm" - btw 8 came and went - sorry!). This is the kind of place you'll want to bring friends,  family, a date - whatever - and stay forever... trying and sharing everything on the menu. Or at least an item or two from each section.

Potato starter thing was so good we got a second!

Stellar squid ink

Rockin risotto. That was lame, I hate that word - rockin', not risotto but that's the best I got right now.  Let's just say nothing I can say will do it justice. 

Donuts with peanut butter and jelly  (sounds gross and I don't like donuts but the waitress schooled me... they are actually beignets !!! Yassssssss.. DO IT!!!!)

I shall return. I shall return. The kind of food that makes you want to hold out eating anything else as it's comparatively far less adventurous, exciting, and Epicurusly...well epic!
author: Tara C.

description:
YAHOO! 

I finally made it to my last in the list of the growing empire from these owners.  (Trestle, Corridor, Fat Angel).

Trestle has my heart and remains my fav, but I love them all.

I referred my friend for a job at my employer, she got the gig and said she would take me to dinner "anywhere" I wanted (within reason of course). NO hesitation I picked here.

We made a reservation for a Thursday evening.  (If you take an Uber there they will take 5% off your bio, which pretty much means they are paying for your transportation there).

I mentioned to the hostess how much I loved Trestle and that I had gotten "review of the day" for my review. She said she remembered it and then brought us both over a glass of champagne (she may do that for everyone, but I am choosing to believe I am a VIP.)

We ordered 2 appetizers to split the egg puffs (the best thing of the night), and the fondue. I ordered the short rib, and my friend got the squid pasta appetizer and a salad.  Everything was great and even my friend commented on how the service was so well tuned to each table - we were more chatty and they were laughing along with us, the tape next to us was on a first date, and they didn't interact too much.

I wanted the PB&J doughnuts when I first read the menu, so my friend had no choice but to go along, they were great.

They did forget to take off the 5% Uber discount off - but promised to do it at nights end when they did the tally.
author: Amy W.

description:
Very cute intimate dining space with great wine selection! Loved the little minimalist details and design of the space.

Had to wait 30 min after our reservation time, frustrating! On the other hand, service was quick and pretty amazing!

I thought the starters were great, but was underwhelmed by the mains. Squid ink pasta is really THAT GOOD. Tuna starter with aguachile is amazing. Potato puff started is so good. And love the duck pate too. Burger had a very unique taste, super delicious, but a bit too much flavor with the croquettes on the side that come with it (they are delicious though). Trout was cooked perfectly with a delicious crispy skin, but I did not like the other components on the plate, especially how they were all separate from each other. Duck was tasty and the presentation was great.

PBnj donuts are a must! Deconstructed tiramisu was beautiful, but isn't really good for sharing if you want to try all the components. Was confused by the lemon ice cream with the tiramisu. 

Loved writing out our childhood favorite desserts to submit at the end, I chose saffron wafer ice cream sandwiches!

Likely will return!
author: Kimia M.

description: Stones Throw Partner Ryan and GM Nicole + Stones throw team made my birthday incredibly memorable. The quality of food is super. We returned again for Chef's tasting course of 13 different plates to taste for the party of 8. Stones Throw is truly a hidden gem and you have to make the reservation much ahead to get a table but all worth it! Excellent wine and beer selection!
author: Kwiri Y.

description: This is a cute little restaurant in a very quintessential SF neighborhood.  The food was divine. If you order beer or wine you do need to go up to the bar and it would be helpful if the waiters explained how ordering drinks worked.  I enjoyed the food and would definitely visit it again. Also, as others have said, take transportation to get here as there is no parking.
author: Virginia T.

description:
So many wonderful flavors going on here!
Started w/ the duck pate and puffed potato. I love pate, and STs was very good, but the puffed potato, w/ egg and cauliflower purée was just OUTSTANDING!! Mid-course was tuna tombo, and the best parts of this plate were the avocado and calamari--superb! For the main course, I chose the burger -- and I am not ashamed!!! So tasty!! Just a bit bigger than a traditional slider, but so damn good!! Tater tots were yummy, too. My wife had the pork tenderloin -- very good, but 2d place to my burger.  Finished the evening w/ PB&J beignets . . . so tasty!  Service?? A+. Wonderful evening!!

Cheers!
RS
author: Rich S.

description:
With a work trip out to San Francisco fast approaching, I knew good food would be a big part of my trip. But the only restaurant I knew ahead of time was Stones Throw as a team dinner with some of the greatest humans to exist. What do you do when you are days away from eating at a place you know will be good? You look at the menu of course. I already had my eye out for things I wanted and things I was going to encourage other to order and share.

Upon arrival, our menus were taken pretty quickly. Having not taken our order and finding out things had been preselected, I saw all of my hopes and dreams of culinary bliss starting to fade away. Until I realized that my boss basically got all of the deliciousness the menu had to offer. I won't be able to remember the details of everything, but I will certainly try.

I was very excited about the pate. It was quite good. But as a lover of pate, I would have preferred to spread it on something that didn't cover the creamy flavor. The puff potato and egg was outstanding. I could have eaten ten of those. The other snack we had were good too... I mean there was nothing that was bad here. But these are the ones that stuck out the most to me.

The squid ink pasta was another one on my hit list and it did not disappoint. If I weren't such a big meat lover, this would have been by far my favorite. I mean it probably was still my favorite... but it just didn't win by a landslide.

The bass was very flavorful and good. But with "crispy-skinned" in the name, I expected to be a little more flavorful. The pork was also full of delicious flavor. But my favorite main was the ribeye and short rib. They complimented each other really well. And for having it preordered, the rareness that I look for was on point.

Great food, great service, great company = 5 stars. Stones Throw you will forever be on my list of places I want to go back to.
author: Will B.

description:
We've been longing to come back to this restaurant for awhile now & it did not disappoint.  Consistent & solid.  Everything about this restaurant is phenomenal - the food, the service, & the ambiance.  The only thing not is the lack of parking in the neighborhood.  I truly believe this is one of the most UNDERRATED restaurants in SF.  (there are SF restaurants that are way way overrated. I won't name names, but the "initials" are.....State Bird Provisions).  I really think Stones Throw should be at least a one Michelin Star restaurant, but I think the Michelin folks probably couldn't find parking to give them the star.  ;-)

Everything on the menu is good, but I highly recommend the:
Duck Liver Mousse, Squid ink pasta, and Bavette Steak.
author: Sequoia S.

description:
Our party of four thoroughly enjoyed our experience at Stones Throw this past weekend. The service from everyone was outstanding, and our server Coleman took great care of us. We also absolutely adored Tai and she took care of us too. We felt like we got the royal treatment. :) 

The space itself is fantastic. It's on the smaller side with an open kitchen, but the noise level is pretty low considering. The restaurant was pretty full when we arrived for our 6pm reservation, so I definitely recommend booking one if you can. 

Everything on the menu sounded amazing, so we each ordered something different to share. We started with an order of the bread, duck pate and mousse, and the crispy Spanish octopus. All three were delicious. Our entrees included the squid ink pasta, steelhead trout, beef short ribs, and the burger. Everything was really good, but the trout seemed a little bland compared to the other dishes. The squid ink pasta was my favorite but the short ribs were a close second. The pasta had great texture and spice, and the short ribs were insanely tender. 

The atmosphere was fun and relaxed with a great wine menu (of course). I highly recommend giving Stones Throw a try and will absolutely go back the next time I'm in San Francisco.
author: Kelly T.

description:
Excellent! Amazing service, quality food, great beer and wine selection. The menu changes seasonally but never disappoints. We've gone here with friends and family, everyone always loves the experience.

Reservations recommended in advance, especially for a larger group. However, they do serve the entire menu at the bar and interacting with the bartenders is always fun.

Highly recommend.
author: Parise S.

description:
We came in with a large group of coworkers... probably sixteen of us cause a few couldn't make it. I started looking over the menu and was instantly interested in a couple items. The puffed potato and egg and the squid ink pasta were a must order for me. Next thing I knew, they were snatching up our menus for as the organizer had pre-ordered a sampling menu. Ruh-roh Shaggy... I love a sampling menu, but I needed those items in my life too.

They brought out multiples of each dish to make sure everyone got a chance to nosh on everything. In total, I think we had thirteen different dishes with three of them being desserts. I definitely won't go into detail on everything as I can't even remember specifics about them all... it was a feast and things started to get blurry. With that many dishes, they wont all be favorites, but there was nothing I didn't care for.

The puffed potato and egg came out early and it was devoured quickly... definitely a winner among the table. As dishes came out one after the other, I became convinced that there would be no squid ink pasta and I began to sulk over my beer in defeat. Just at that moment, the pasta hit the table and I let out a sigh of relief. Everything I had built up in my head about it was true and the pasta had such a distinct flavor. It's not for everyone, but was definitely a table favorite as well. I could have definitely done another order just for myself.

After tasting ninety percent of the menu in one sitting, I look forward to coming back for dinner and ordering on my own. You can be sure that squid ink pasta will be on the list. Other things to look forward to are the impressive beer list of which I was too full to do much sampling. I did throw a couple IPAs back though. The other thing worth noting was the service. We had a large party, and a few who didn't make it last minute. The staff did a phenomenal job with our table and truly made the whole service look effortless. Cheers to them and Stones Throw for an amazing group dinner.
author: Scotty C.

description:
Two of my gal pals and I came to this cute and contemporary restuarant nestled on top of Russian Hill for dinner (lured in by the Yelp reviews). We were one of the first ones there around 5:30p but the place quickly filled up with affluent looking diners. 

We enjoyed the simple and seasonal menu and settled on an order of potato and egg puffs, soup, squid ink pasta and 3 of the rib eye/ short rib entrees. We all enjoyed the potato puffs which were light despite the rich cream sauce. My friend's vegetable soup (I want to say corn) was poured table side over a bed of flowers/  leaves and had great flavor from the few bites I tasted.
