The squid ink conchiglie was good but nothing too exciting. Our rib eyes were unfortunately a little overdone despite our "medium" request and I had to ask for extra sauce/ au jus to remoisten and flavor it. The dessert menu was unappealing but we did like the option to write in our own dessert suggestion with the cute birch looking golf pencils. 

Service was a bit aloof but our waters were refilled often and the pace of dinner was great. 

Value was poor at $55 pp without drinks after tax and tip (and no dessert!). We thought the servings were a little small and the food was solid but not anything too exciting; this reminds me of a younger Jardinere.  The quality was great, however, and the venue is very bright and clean. I'd return for the potato puffs or drinks after I've tried some other eateries on Russian/Nob Hill.
author: Angela L.

description:
I had this place bookmarked for a while. Coincidentally, this is the spot my buddy picked out for dinner! I was super excited about it, except that I have been eating vegetarian for a month now. Surprisingly, they had a lot of options for me. To start, we had the puff potatoes and eggs. My friend went with the pate! We both enjoyed our starter dishes. The portion size is super tiny, but it's enough to share between two people. I highly recommend ordering at least two appetizers to start. We didn't share because I was not eating meat at the time we visited this spot. 

For dinner, I ordered the ravioli and my buddy had the ahi. Also, excellent choices! Again, the portions are tiny, but surprisingly, I didn't finish my meal. I saved a portion for the next day. For dessert, we ordered the sundae which came with Neapolitan ice cream and chocolate covered bananas! I think it's neat that they change up the dessert menu based on diner's favorite desserts growing up. They give you a questionnaire at the end of dinner, and if they end up selecting your favorite dessert, they invite you back to try out their recreation. I didn't think of my favorite dish until now, but I will have to find a way to email them and let them know what my favorite desserts were growing up (aside from ice cream). 

The service here is awesome! Our servers and their assistants were all equally attentive. From the front greeter to the bus boys, they are all personable. I really enjoyed this place and look forward to my next visit for sure! Definitely a place I recommend and would like to come back to!
author: Jenn R.

description:
We have been to stones throw a few times now and this restaurant continues to floor us every time. The food is always delicious and the service great. Went with a few friends, a couple of days ago- ordered multiple things-
1- puffed potato and eggs- A staple. Always perfect, always delicious. A must must try.
2- marinated calamari and Burrata- yummy
3- summer squash soup- is a super hit. It was so delicious with a hint of curry flavor. We ended up ordering one of each person on the table
4- Halibut Crudo- was nice and fresh. The fish was tasty.
5-Spanish octopus- another super star. There are very few places that can do octopus right and this is one of them. It was meaty, juicy, not tough - melted in your mouth.
6- Steelhead trout- For entree, I had steelhead trout. The fish was flavorful, the sauce and the beans were tasty.

There service was really good too. They kept checking on us through out the night, our water glasses were always full (and I drink a lot of water). Friend of mine wanted a wine bottle but did not like the first bottle they brought, so they took back the entire bottle that they opened for us and got us a different bottle. Sweet. Highly recommend this place.
author: Chet L.

description: Ok, just finished brunch.  First things first.. bottomless mimosas!  Ok 2 hr limit, but seriously, how many mimosas can you drink in 2 hours? Yes, that was a challenge!  The Sunday Brunch was awesome and very affordable (prix fix).  Started with a bread plate, followed by a main course  ( a pancake for the wife & pork belly frittata for me) and peach Bellini donuts for dessert.  Did I mention service was outstanding?  It was.  This place is a hidden jem.
author: michael c.

description:
We had a dinner reservation here tonight and warned them ahead we'd be ordering vegan. They came up with an incredible meal; avocado toast, grilled pear salad and a main dish with quinoa, seasonal veggies and pureed peas. All in all it was excellent. I have some weird allergies, and they were super accommodating.

One thing to note is they did a whole pre-fixe thing which took a little longer than just ordering off the menu due to the amount of courses. So, plan to spend 1.5-2 hours.
author: Michelle V.

description:
The flavor and quality of the food here is A+, ambiance is decent for what you'd expect from a restaurant in this tier, and the service is good. My overall experience was completely marred by the fact that our estimated table wait was off by almost an hour. Granted, we didn't have a reservation, but it involved a lot of waiting.

Would say the main draw is great dining but casual and clean interior. The donuts are great for dessert!
author: Amy G.

description:
Popped in with my husband and we both agreed, some of the best service we've ever had. it doesn't take much to feel welcomed but they really do it well here. 

We both had burgers and they do them really well. I sheepishly always ask if I can have an extra order of tater tots - they're really really good. Also, get the puffed potato and egg, I still want to know the secret behind that recipe!
author: Marlyn F.

description:
The duck was cooked perfectly.  Really couldn't ask for more.  Crispy on the outside but medium on the inside.  So flavorful.  Wasn't a big fan of the sour pickled huckleberries but more of a preference thing.  

Only thing holding this review back is the steak sounded like everything I dream about, gratin potatoes, asparagus, bernaise, and they were sold out at a reasonable dinner hour.
author: JD S.

description: The service here is outstanding and knowledgeable not just about the food but also the cocktail, wine and beer menu.  The portions are on the small side, you are def going to want an app or 2 for everyone and a main dish - be prepared for an expensive evening however the food is balanced and very tasty.
author: James N.

description: I was rather disappointed by our meal. We were quite hungry, so the rather small portion size was not filling. Additionally, our mushroom ravioli (and I believe my friend got the short rib entree) was decent but not memorable. The flavors of both dishes were subdued.
author: Rei T.

description:
Perhaps my mistake was coming in with too high of expectations. Nevertheless, I had a decent meal and experience here. 

Service was spectacular, with the servers never missing an opportunity to top our glasses off. And the Sangiovese Uccelliera that wine our server suggested was enjoyable. My complaints (or failure, really, to be impressed) had more to do with the dishes. 

We started with the duck pate, potato puffs, and squid ink pasta. Out of these, I would only order the potato puffs again - the puff just sort of melts in your mouth. For our entrees, my friend ordered the salmon and I opted for "da burga." I was bummed to see they weren't offering the bass anymore, because salmon is well, salmon... The whole experience was a little underwhelming to say the least. My burger was definitely over cooked but I wasn't much in the mood to complain about it (the irony is that I spent 3 years of my life working at a burger joint, having faced the back end of complaints about patty temperatures). The salmon was also *just okay* (a recurring theme here).

For dessert, we shared the peanut butter jelly donuts. I was pleasantly surprised, the soft beignets and the pb&j really did complement each other well. I appreciate the concept of the dessert menu - upscale renditions of childhood favorites. It was fun to write my own down as an inspiration suggestion for the dessert chef. 

Overall, this is not a place I would choose to return to, based on the food quality alone. That, however, is barely an insult to any restaurant in SF considering the multitude of options we have here. Nevertheless, I can dig the vibe, service, drink menu, and space of the place. Worth a stop on the SF eater trail but don't have high expectations.
author: Liz C.

description: First time dining food was delicious. Ordered the steak, duck, squid ink pasta and dessert. Every dish was well seasoned and explained perfectly by staff. The only thing that made this dining experience disappointing was the cocktails they offered. Ordered a couple cocktails and it was as if I had ordered non alcoholic drinks. Drinks really lacked alcohol and we by far too sweet. I would highly not recommend cocktails here.
author: Ivan C.

description: We had an absolutely incredible time at Stone's Throw!  Everything was delicious, and the staff was incredibly kind and courteous!  The peanut butter and jelly donuts are so good - my fiancée and I had been dreaming about them for months after the last time we came here, so we just had to come back.  My favorite restaurant in San Francisco, hands down!
author: Jacek W.

description:
This was a great dining and drinking experience.
We came without reservation, but were promptly seated at the bar and could enjoy watching the skilled bartenders.

I don't think you can go really wrong with any of the choices here. The menu is short and solid. The presentation is fantastic. Not a place to get stuffed, but more to enjoy beautifully prepared and thought over meal.

They have a pretty impressive beer menu, which was a great deal for meWould definitely come back
author: Damian M.

description: I love trying new things and Stones Throw definitely opened up my mind to being adventurous with food. One of the things that I tried here that I loved was the Squid Ink Conchiglie Pasta. It was something I haven't had before but it was worth a try! Didn't think I would be a fan of it but here I am, loving it to death! It didn't look too appetizing at first but it's delicious, unique and something I will be having again in the future. I also liked the Pork Belly dish and the carbonara from here. Compared to other places, it could be much better, but for me it was passable. I recommend checking out Stones Throw; try the squid ink pasta!
author: Johanna A.

description:
I swear we ate just about everything on the menu, and I'm still fantasizing about it days later. The ambiance was lovely, bustling yet intimate. The space didn't seem to have any detail left unconsidered - everything from the decor to the menus, stoneware, and pencils they provide with dessert all shine with the same charming personality. The service was attentive and friendly... Plus we were able to get a reservation the night before for a 6:30pm dinner service. 

But the food! Everyone has already written about the puffed potato and egg starter for good reason! It's so well executed and amazing! The dish I can't stop thinking about was the creamy gnudi, rich with ricotta flavor, but complimented by the butternut squash with a little crunch from the kale. We had the squid ink pasta, hamachi, braised beef short rib and the duck too, all beautifully composed, but I was sadly too stuffed to fully appreciate by then. Lastly, dessert included the adorable and tasty choco tacos, but the peanut butter and jelly donuts stole the show. I never would have ordered it, but you must! The light and fluffy donut is amazing against the sweetness of the jelly and richness of the creamy peanut sauce, sprinkled with some crunchy peanuts. 

So. Much. Yumminess.
author: Nikki J.

description:
Had a lovely dinner at Stones Throw and the service was A+. Other restaurants should take note. They were super attentive, didn't spend forever rattling off specials on the menu, the water glass was always filled, and they surprised us with a PB&J dessert at the end! 

The highlights were the squid ink pasta and puffed potato & egg, although the amberjack crudo (a new item that they added to the menu that day) was also refreshing and tasty. I would recommend those three items. The duck pate was also solid but I wish it was accompanied by a different type of bread instead of a soft pretzel. That's just a personal preference.

My fiancé and I split "Da Burga," and to be honest I wasn't overly impressed. While good, it tasted like a standard burger to me and I wasn't sure what made it worth $16. The tater tots were nicely done, but I wish there were more of them. 

The dessert menu is fun and I love the concept of asking people to write down their favorite childhood desserts. They pick a few to incorporate into future menus.

What I liked most is that it was "fine dining" in a relaxed environment. It felt like eating creative food in a neighborhood restaurant and I didn't feel like it was too stuffy at all. Would love to check out their brunch sometime.
author: Valerie L.

description:
Da burger is da bomb, forealz!

I've eaten at this place twice already. The BF and I enjoy this place very much and just about everything on their menu. We do have our favorite; which is "Da burger", but for the most part everything is made very well. The chef's tasting profile is on point in my opinion. This place has over 500+ reviews, and it's just about at 5 stars. I think that tell you a lot. There's not much I can say that hasn't been said.

Food was great, it can be pricey, parking totally sucks, service was super friendly and attentive. This place is now one of our favorites, but mainly as the BF's "best tasting burger" he ever had type of thing.
author: Lena T.

description:
Came by with a reservation via OpenTable the other night and was certainly glad that I did as I was seated immediately upon arrival to a full restaurant! Parking in Russian Hill is challenging and the restaurant does offer 5% off your bill for using Uber.

The restaurant itself is unique as it's in an older building. There are even a couple standing tables by the door near the bar for a casual meal!

Started off with the squid ink conchiglie pasta which was on the salty side. The pasta had a fantastic texture and the seafood tasted fresh!

Moved on to the puffed potato & eggs and this one was lackluster. It was sort of bland, although it was unique in the sense that it had an egg yolk inside the puff potato! The cauliflower mousse and crispy chicken skin was a unique add-on to the dish.

The spring vegetable salad was very good. Vegetables were fresh and the custard made the salad filling!

I was a big fan of Da Burga as the bread was light and fluffy! The burger patty was freshly made and crumbled nicely with the bread. I also enjoyed the coleslaw that blended quite well with the burger. The tater tots were okay.

Ended off the meal with the Peanut Butter & Jelly Donuts which was the highlight of the meal. The beignets were light and fluffy (if only they could make them filled!) The peanut butter and jelly with the dish complemented this dessert quite well!

Ambiance of the restaurant was more on the casual side as it was pretty loud inside and the tables were pretty close together... Staff was friendly! 

~$45/head after tax and tip. There is a ~5% SF Health charge for the wait staff.
author: Derek S.

description:
Ambiance: 4 stars
Food for the price you pay: 2 stars :(

Look, I'm not one to completely bad mouth a restaurant in an unproductive manner, unless something is really wrong with the food or service. With Stones Throw, I just wanted to give an honest opinion to those that are curious or eager to try it (as we were, and I feel the glowing reviews left us very, very unsatisfied). 

For starters - let's start with the positives. This is an artsy/pretty spot, nice decor and ambiance. We took a 5:45pm reservation as that's all that was  available, and again from the positive reviews, I was sure this would be a great meal and worth the ridiculously early reservation time. The drinks we ordered were creative - nothing amazing, but they had a unique flare, so in terms of ambiance and decor (and the drinks), I'd give this place a 4. 

FOOD. Simply put, out of the 3 dishes we ordered, we did not like any. Honest truth. We ordered the Hamachi Crudo which to our surprise (I went with my husband, we order crudo often), the fish was very very fishy/not fresh tasting at all. What? For $16 you do not even get freshly sliced crudo? It was apparent by the look and taste. Very disappointing. We are NOT the couple to send items back, but we left it untouched after trying 1 piece, and the bartender noticed we didn't touch it and sent our waiter over ( ** Really appreciated that the bartender noticed this and took care of it by telling our waiter). The waiter was kind about us not liking the dish, said he would talk to the chef, and took it off our bill. We really do appreciate that.

Entrees - My husband ordered beef ($32) and I ordered Agnolotti. Apparently the $16 on the menu for agnolotti is for the appetizer portion - when asked if I wanted the appetizer or dinner size, I said the dinner size, not realizing that you are paying $25 for like 6 agnolotti (which was "ok") and a bunch of celery root. Really??? I was left VERY hungry still, so we had to go to another meal after this (nuts, I've never had to do that). My husband said his beef was "just ok" and disliked all the garnishes that came with it. I tried a bite and disliked it as well.

All in all prices are very very high for what you get, and we were  dissatisfied with our meal. We left, went to a wine bar and had to order cheese and meats as I was still starving (!). 

I regret the $100+ dollars we spent. Overall, no, I would not recommend this place or return again. Hope you have better luck than we did if you try it.
author: R S.

description:
With so many top flight restaurants in SF it is difficult to find an unique place that is worth a try.  
The reviews and pictures of some of Stones Throw's dishes caught my eye as I was searching for a place to visit while in SF.

The parking let most places around Russian Hill is difficult and there is no valet parking.  If you can, I'd recommend taking the cable car or Uber; it'll save you 20 - 30 minutes of circling around for a parking spot.

Stones Throw is a casual eatery with some inventive dishes.  The service was very attentive and vibe of the patrons while hip is not pretentious.  As far as the food, it was quite decent and beautifully plated; but, it didn't really wow me as I would expect from a 4.5 start joint in SF.

The duck pate & mousse was mild in flavor and was overpowered by the mustard seeds; the pretzel was also not as moist and soft and I would like.  The Potato Puff and Egg was a very pretty dish and the soft-boiled egg in the center was a good contrast in texture; flavor was also on the mild side.

The squid ink conchiglie pasta was our favorite with bold and complex flavors with perfectly cooked handmade black shell pasta. The anh mi style pork belly indeed tasted like a deconstructed banh mi.  It was an inventive concept; I just wish the pork was a little more moist.

The duo of ribeye and short rib was quite tender.  Perhaps I am just expecting too much; but, I didn't find taste wise anything that differentiated it from the short rib dishes served in other run of the mill steak houses.  I think infusing either summer plum, winter kumquat, or any citrus to the braising process would really accentuate the flavor.

The 38 North duck breast was cooked to the perfect tenderness, which was a sign of a skilled chef.  Once again, other than the tartness of the rhubarb, there was not much texture or excitement to the flavors.

As for the desserts, the best part of the peach melba was the ice cream. The BP&J donuts was well done and was quite pleasing.

All in all, not a bad place and was reasonably priced.  I just expected a little more based on the Yelp rating.
author: Louis C.

description:
We did a set menu and everything was amazing! The squid ink dish was by far my favorite thing. The flavors were rich and I think I could have eaten just a giant bowl of that.

SQUID INK CONCHIGLIE PASTA 
Spicy Capers, Clams, Calamari, Shrimp, Tender Greens
author: Schelly Y.

description:
What a unique and special experience! Stones Throw and renowned Chef, Dominique Crenn came together and prepared an incredible 5-course meal and ALL proceeds went to charity!  I've never had an experience quite like this.. "At its best, cooking is an alchemical process that transforms ingredients beyond the simple chemical reactions sparked by heat and cold, oil and acid. The act of cooking is an engagement with tradition, community, time and place. And for me, cooking it poetry". Dominique Crenn. 
Dominique describes making food as an Art and it is very important to use all 5 senses; seeing, tasting, hearing, touching and smelling, to really understand this art form!. I may not be able to explain and articulate each dish quite as they did, but I can share my experience visually. :) (See photos)

Service: Without a hitch! 6 star! ;) They were so knowledgeable about each dish and gave great detail in the preparation. Their professionalism and explanation from each of the Servers was impressive. 

Food:
Pre-course (to cleanse the palate): A white chocolate ball filled with champagne topped with  raspberry gel. Its very delicate and pops in your mouth. (Very cleverly created)  
First Course - Spring Pea Salad with smoked trout, brioche and Hen egg
Second Course - Poached Striped Bass, with asparagus, little gems and lemon agrumato
Third Course - Monterey Squid with lardo, potato and smoked ham broth. With fried ink chips
Fourth Course - Aged Duck with beets and wild berries
Fifth Course - Raspberry Clafoutis - A Lemon curd, angel food cake and crème de violette

The combination of ingredients made for incredible flavors. There is definitely a science behind their creations, which made the experience and taste utterly amazing!

Location: In Mission Hill, in a cute residential area. Street parking available.

Price: $76 per person all inclusive (We pre-paid in advance for this special event).
We brought 2 bottles of wine which they accommodated. 

Loved every minute of this place.. I'll be back!
author: Anie L.

description: I really enjoyed the attentive yet non stuffy service.  The food was nice traditional dishes with enough creativity to be interesting.  The burger was very nice
author: Nicolas G.

description:
This place had more hype than Beyonce's debut album, and both seemed to disappoint to tickle my fancy!?! 

We had reservations at noon, we arrived about 15mins early and they told us to wait outside for a few mins until a table clears up and then they will call us in.  So we sat outside on a bench like hobos waiting for our name to be called. I see another couple walk in and when we went inside to go check at noon to see if our table was ready, they were seated before us and no our table for 2 is still is not ready, but there's is?!? So we had to wait another 10 mins and this time I just stood right in front of the hostess giving her the "Eastside San Jose death look" so she doesn't give our table away again!?! #SoFrustrating

Also the menu is very simple, not a lot of selection but that is fine as long as the dishes are good "Quality over Quantity" like I always tell my playas.

The Original Cup - super gingery if you're into that

Salmon Mousse Dip - really good, best thing we ordered, not enough bread given for the dip amount though so make sure you ask for seconds

Duck Confit Entree - dry, small portion, really expensive, disappointment

Spicy Eggs w/Polenta & Pork Belly in Tomato sauce - not really spicy, a-ok, nothing special 

I don't know playas?...despite all the high Yelp ratings I was not impressed.  The food was like 3.7, the service was like 3.1, I wish I could give it a higher rating but I can't, and I won't, and as Arnold would not say "I won't be back"...
author: Deep S.

description: We had great experience here!   The staff was very welcoming and professional, drinks and food were delicious, although the fish dish (fish special recommended for 2) was slightly bland.  We would definitely try this place out again!
author: Ryan S.

description:
I found this gem by chance and I've been coming back at least once a week ever since.

It's the perfect place to go out with friends or on a date. The staff is extremely friendly and attentive, the first time I went they waited for us to finish until after 10pm when the restaurant closes. 
The food is delicious and easy to share. I usually order 3-4 different things then share them. I tried everything on their menu and it's absolutely delicious, but my favorites are the burrata, the spanish octopus and the pork chop. Make sure save space for dessert - they have this "back to childhood menu" that will send you dreaming!

Definitely recommend it!
author: Delia Z.

description:
Small menu that changes seasonally. All the dishes we ordered were considerably well prepared and delicious. 

My favorites: 

+ Puffed Potato and Eggs (cauliflower mousse, chives, crispy chicken skin) 
+ Crispy-skinned trout (celery root, roasted Brussels sprouts, beef jus)
author: Merica S.

description: Very sweet experience! It was my anniversary with my husband, they prepared card and a little candle sweets! The squid pasta was very delicious! Also the octopus salad with cracker was awesome too! The wine they recommended was from Germany, very sweet and easy to drink! Also everything is about good price!!
author: Shiqi L.

description:
This place was fantastic. Review based on Sunday brunch. 

It's a non-flashy exterior located near the top of Russian Hill. Fits into the neighborhood well. When you walk inside, it's a really cool atmosphere with interesting decoration and an open kitchen. 

There's an extensive bottle list that will satisfy beer snobs like me. Sadly it was too early for me to drink. Brunch cocktails looked cool, but that isn't our thing. 

We split the strawberry doughnuts, which were AMAZING. Like best doughnuts ever. Fresh, soft outside and the strawberry filling was delicious. Served with tasty whipped cream. 

They have a chili verde brunch dish, which has pork belly and poached eggs swimming in the verde sauce. Extremely flavorful and unique. Served with avocado toast that was executed very well: perfectly toasted bread and with pickled onions and fresh herbs. Their pancake was also very good (but not as good as the chili verde).

Really happy we checked this place out while in town for a just a couple days.
author: Ben H.

description: I was unexpectedly blown away by every dish I tried, from the pulled potato and eggs, to the hamachi crudo, to the tender and flavorful scallops, and finally the entire dessert menu. The service was excellent - attentive, knowledgeable wait staff definitely enhanced the experience. I can't wait to go back! And it'll definitely be for the scallops and the beignets.
author: Alison S.

description: Decent food for the price. Had the hamachi crudo which was good, campagnalle with braised beef Sufi which was bland and not that much food, and the burger was really just OK, and the foster tots weren't great. With glasses of wine each it was $60 per person which just wasn't worth it to me. Wasn't a bad meal overall, but wouldn't go back
author: Diana A.

description:
Dinner review. Great decor and lively environment, with some unique and tasty dishes. They have an extensive beer and wine menu from all over the world, which was a nice touch.

We started with the puffed potato and eggs, which tasted exactly like how it sounds, like a small flavor explosion in your mouth. Next, we had the charred Spanish octopus and seared tombo tuna. The tuna was seared perfectly, but the octopus was much more memorable. One of the best I've had in SF. Finally, we shared the braised beef shortrib. The meat was flavorful and fall-off-the-bone tender, exactly what I was looking for. We finished the meal with the tiramisu, which was a unique, deconstructed take on the dish. It was presented beautifully and tasted nice, but not in the least bit traditional.

Will be back to try the squid ink pasta, pan roasted trout, duck breast, and brunch menu. Keep up the good stuff!
author: Tim X.

description: Stones Throw is one of those places that I love to go especially for their super fresh pasta. I wasn't feeling for the ordinary and I wanted to get something unique so ordered the Squid Ink Conchiglie Pasta (I did not even know this restaurant had a dish like this but the waiter strongly recommended it). And he was absolutely right; this pasta was 100% mouth-watering. This entree has conchiglie (a shell-shaped ink pasta) with seafood and a very light sauce. I also had an order of puffed potatoes, and I was able to try a few pieces of the kurobuta pork chop my friend ordered for himself. The pork chop wasn't bad but it was a bit dry and the puffed potatoes were probably the best thing I had all night. For dessert we shared the peanut butter and jelly donuts concord. To be honest I did like them but they weren't that great or as great I was hoping. For the prices, these dishes were fine and our server was professional and on point. Stones Throw again soon, at least to see if my next rating improves to four stars or five stars.
author: Tara M.

description:
Leave no STONE unturned.

My brother kindly took my mom, myself, and some friends to dinner on our last night in the bay area.  I found out that same night that he was wanting to try this restaurant for some time, and he thought a "last supper" with the family was a good reason for an inaugural visit.

And about that STONE being unturned, I guess in this case the STONE would be a metaphor for the menu.  My advice:  peruse the menu carefully as there are certainly many appetizing dishes to choose from.

The restaurant is cozy, yet elegant and simply decorated.  Though we were slightly early for our reservation, the host extended a warm welcome and showed our group of five to our table.

Some of the group did their due diligence in researching (via Yelp) the more popular or well-known dishes.  However, their menu has many appetizers, entrees, etc. to choose from, as well as an extensive wine and spirits list.

FOOD:  Thanks to some helpful recommendations via Yelp, our group chose a variety of appetizers to share, these included the puffed potato and eggs, duck pate & mousse, and the squid ink pasta.  

Firstly, do order the puffed potato and eggs and the squid ink pasta.  All of the accolades from other yelpers are indeed true.  The potato and eggs are fluffy, light and delicious, while the pasta delivers bold flavors thanks to the seafood combination of calamari, squid, shrimp, and clams.  The duck pate and mousse was alright, and I'd recommend asking for more bread if needed.  

My dinner entree was the butternut squash ravioli.  It was simply divine.  Cheesey goodness is more like it actually.  Although the portion was smaller than I anticipated, the gnnochi was excellent.  The brussels sprout pesto, truffle, and sage complemented the ricotta gnudi splendidly.  In contrast, my mother ordered the trout, accompanied with brussels sprouts, celery root and beef jus.  She liked it every much, as evident by her finishing almost the entire portion.

I think the entree our table was most in awe of was the burger, or "DA BURGA" as its aptly named on the menu.  This entree is of gargantuan proportions and is every bit as mouthwatering as it looks.....from what I was told by my two tablemates that ordered this behemoth burger.  The burger bun is equally just as thick as the meat that sits between the two pieces, which barely contained the melted cheddar cheese that slowly trickled onto the plate.  And its companion?  Not just your ordinary fries, but baked potato tator tots.  I was able to try a tator tot, and after doing so I began to doubt my original decision to order the gnnochi.  I suppose a second visit is in order on a future trip to the bay area.

SWEET TREAT:  To end the meal, we all shared the peanut butter and jelly donuts.  For all my Hawaii friends and family on Yelp, this is basically the bay area's version of malasadas.  The generous portion of jelly within the donut was, of course, a fantastic combination with the peanut butter and truly brought back fond childhood memories.  A comfort food and dessert rolled into one.  

SERVICE:  Outstanding.  Our server was a friendly and humorous woman who was extremely patient with our group, and took the time to answer all our questions to the best of her ability.  She kindly offered recommendations on appetizers, entrees, and cocktails.  She checked on us in a timely during the entire meal and provided excellent customer service.  

BOTTOM LINE:  An incredible meal with wonderful friends and family.  I'll be back to try "DA BURGA" for sure!!  Those peanut butter and jelly donuts are awesome!
author: Michael C.

description:
Why 5 stars? Because we ate just about everything, and just about everything was magnificent. 

   ---   ---   ---

This was a large work dinner, and from afar, you would have thought we were *super* important people, because we were getting treated like royalty. In reality, we were just a bunch of regular Joe's and JoAnne's who love eating and individually taking 13 pictures of each plate of food brought out. Doing the math 13 x 8 or 9 courses x 15ish people... a lot of film was burned that night.

If you're looking for a spot with that can hold a group about that size, Stone's Throw has a nice area toward the back that can accommodate such a thing, but be sure to book plenty in advance.

Things we ate:

Pate - Very solid. I wish we had a little more of this.

Smoked fish and peas - Think 'fancy 7 layer dip' - once again, I wanted more!

Puffed Potatoes - Unfreaking believable. Possibly the best thing all night.

Squid Ink Pasta - Not the best squid ink pasta I've ever had, but still very tasty.

Pork Belly - I am kind of down on pork belly more than most people, but they did a really good job on this.

Peanut Butter and Jelly Donuts - A great way to finish off a wonderful meal.

Everything ranged from good to great, and the service was on top of it, despite our party being large and obnoxious with laughter all night. Once again, San Francisco flexes its muscles as the best food city in the U.S.
author: Brett N.

description:
I've been here a few times. Excellent service our server was very friendly. Love the way they plated. The food was great along with awesome wine selections. 
FYI parking can be hassle especially on a weekend night.
author: Thanakris W.

description: Service was excellent. Decor felt hip but comfortable - like your favorite pair of Paige jeans. Dimly lit, unpretentious, and definitely date night worthy. Food was absolutely delicious. Finished every bite and left feeling satisfied and satiated. Would definitely come again but would skip the donuts next time. Stones Throw is a favorite for sure!
author: tpt T.

description: Had a great group dinner late comers.  Manager accommodating and added chairs to welcome late guests. Bravo
author: Aloha M.

description:
Experience...
Was sited at the wrong table, music they they play isn't that nice.

Ordered a Truffle risotto , it didn't taste like truffles at all!!
author: Lana S.

description:
This is an easy one. 5 stars for the ambience, the menu, the great service, and of course, the fantastic food!

As a Californian/American restaurant, Stones Throw keeps the menu simple. Sharing is caring - the plates are small but if you work your way through the menu you'll get a great variety. Highlights: PUFFED POTATO & EGGS, SAUSAGE STUFFED GRILLED QUAIL, and the TAMARIND-GLAZED BEEF RIBEYE.

For the drinks Stones Throw focuses on local wines and German beer.  Extra kudos for the waiter who spoke a little bit of German when I ordered my BERLINER WEISSE MIT SCHUSS - a local classic from Berlin. I was very surprised to find it on the menu.

What I especially like about Stones Throw is the attention to detail. You'll find historic references to their food and drinks on the menu, and even the toilet is equipped with a little history on the building. After your dining experience you can leave feedback if you find anything missing from the menu. Neat idea - it's the little things that count.
author: Sebastian F.

description:
If you choose to eat there, do NOT have high expectations! When we made the reservations for a party of seven for Sunday brunch and had to leave a credit card number, we received two different texts to make sure we would show up. Being a party of seven, we ordered every item on the beach menu including the snacks that were for sharing. Not impressed! In fact four of us left most of their food untouched because we didn't like it even though the portions were rather small and way too expensive for what it was. The place is also not vegetarian friendly at all.
We ended up in a different restaurant shortly after because we were hungry!
author: Shabnam N.

description:
I really enjoyed this place. The food is very delicious and the staff is nice and accommodating.
I would definitely come back for food and atmosphere. 
Duck Pate and Summer Squash soup are to die for!!!
author: Mariya Delilah D.

description: We found this place on yelp and surprisedly the food was very delicious. Great service as well. Worth to give a try. Will definitely go back again.
author: L C.

description: Served a dip that tasted like sour cream and onion dip from Safeway with 5 stale cold potato chips. Asked for a few more chips and was charged extra. Very underwhelming.
author: Nikki F.

description:
This is seriously the worst 4.5 stars restaurant in Yelp. It should only deserve .5 stars.

The food was tasteless. The waiters were pushy. The duck was hard as rock. Where was the crudo in the crudo? What are those dried up twigs next to the crudo?

Do yourself a favor and skip this establishment.

Seriously... Dinner conversation... Interrupted by waiters at least 25 times in a span of 1 hour while being served mediocre food.
author: Koalie W.

description:
I normally have a birthday dinner with my coworkers every year. This year, we celebrated a little later than usual. A couple weeks prior, I made a reservation through OpenTable for a party of 4 for Thursday, October 15th at 6:30pm.

Food:
*PUFFED POTATO & EGGS: Cauliflower Mousse, Chives, Crispy Chicken Skin ($8)
*DUCK PÂTÉ & MOUSSE: French's Mustard, Cornichons, Warm Soft Pretzel ($8)
*SQUID INK CONCHIGLIE PASTA: Spicy Capers, Clams, Calamari, Shrimp, Tender Greens ($15 x1.5 for Main portion = $22.50)
*38 NORTH DUCK BREAST: Duck Confit, Crispy Polenta, Tokyo Turnips, Huckleberries, Hazelnuts ($28)
*"DA BURGA" aka DA DISASTER: Dressed & Ready, 'Everything' Baked Potato Tater Tots ($16)
*PEANUT BUTTER & JELLY DONUTS

I know everyone raves about the puffed potato and eggs, but for me, what blew me away were the baked potato tater tots. I already love tater tots. Stones Throw then goes and stuffs them with baked potato toppings?! I'm in heaven! For my entree, I got the duck breast which was perfectly cooked! Crispy skin, tender meat. We all shared the puffed potato appetizer. I thought they were good, but they didn't exactly blow my mind. Maybe I needed to eat more than one to fully appreciate it?

One of my coworkers wanted the squid ink pasta, but it was listed under starters so she was afraid the portion would've been too small for a main. The restaurant was nice enough to make her an entree sized portion which ended up being 1.5 times the starter price. They were also very sweet and gave us the donut dessert for my birthday.

Wines by the glass:
*Sauvignon Blanc Scarbolo, Friuli, Italy 2014 ($11)
*Chardonnay Talley 'Bishop's Peak', San Luis Obispo, CA 2014 ($9)
*Cabernet Sauvignon Medlock Ames 'Bell Mountain', Alexander Valley, CA 2012 ($14)

We all decided to do wines by the glass since one coworker ordered beer and we all had different glasses of wine. The wines were decently priced and I enjoyed my cab with the duck.

Very fun place to have dinner and for a casual special occasion.
author: Elena N.

description: Great food. Great service. Wonderful staff. First time my mother said "yummy" in my entire life.
author: Ellan R.

description: Highly recommend potato puffs, duck breast and short ribs.  Great atmosphere and good cocktails too!!
author: Christine A.

description:
This restaurant is meant for some sort of special occasion just because the tapa-sized, delectable and variety of dishes are meant to be shared with someone other than one self!  That's exactly what I came to do.  Made reservations, should have mentioned that it was my birthday and arrived to celebrate that special occasion. 

My group was late to the appointed time, as I expected and the hostess mentioned to me that they have a turnover time.  Both factors contributed to my dining experience mood.  It didn't help that the waitress didn't quite pair well with my taste buds on wine preference at that moment. She kept suggesting while my friend didn't have a clue.  I wanted French and smooth, clean taste while she said that French was of the opposite spectrum.  I became irritated at that point.  

I was beginning to think that maybe it was anxiety.

Nonetheless, my party finally arrived and I got to get my munchies on.  Pate paired with my French wine, (Yes, I get what I want) was a teaser.  The pate was so minuscule and it didn't have much taste that I usually like in pate.  The Duck breast was savory and the nicely cooked Scallops, were succulent.  Ribeye was of the norm.

The Squid ink conchigile pasta was unique!  That caught my taste palate.  Finely creamy with texture and lovely ink flavor.  Decadent for the most part. 

Continued on with Pork ears and no desserts.  My whoopla group didn't mention it was my birthday so I didn't get a special treat nor felt like it was a special occasion after all.

It's a miss this time around in terms of setting the mood for fine dining affair with a special occasion.  Unfortunately.
author: Tiffany D.

description:
Recently returned for brunch after two years and still enjoyed it!

We ordered the Pork Belly Tomato Sauce with Baked Eggs & Avocado Toast ($15) and the Salmon Mousse ($8) along with two glasses of wine. This was the perfect size to share between two people. The mousse was delicious but light and airy, and the baked eggs were super delicious on top of Polenta and the side of avo toast was delightful!

Overall, a solid option for brunch fare as well in the Russian Hill area!
author: Veronica S.

description: I ordered squid pasta for entree. Food was alright. Nothing really stands out to me. Their customer service was excellent. They keep on making sure everything goes okay with us. They do charge $5 cake fee. We brought a cake for our friend's birthday.
author: Donna D.

description:
I'm absolutely blown away by how good their brunch is, especially because my boyfriend and I came here around 11:30AM on a Sunday and we were immediately seated. Who needs to wait two hours for brunch when places like Stones Throw exist? But seriously, it has been a long time since I actually stopped after my first bite of food at a restaurant just to marvel how good it tastes.

We started with the Puffed Potatoes and Egg with Cauliflower Mousse, Crispy Bacon. Amazing and would recommend anyone to visit Stones Throw just to try this dish. (For dinner, the bacon is actually replaced by crispy chicken skin.) The mousse is perfectly fluffy, and the flavor was not overshadowed by the bacon.

Our experience with the Puffed Potatoes also made me appreciate their impressive service too. The waiter serving us at the bar was knowledgeable about the menu, and he actually described step-by-step how the potatoes were prepared when we asked! He told us about how the egg yolks are frozen, then the puffed potato is built around the egg yolk and frozen again. And when it's time to prepare the dish, five of the balls are fried, and one of them is split open as a test to make sure the rest of them are fully cooked. DANG. I need to ask my servers more often how these dishes are prepared!

For our entrees, we had the Duck Confit Hash and Spicy Tomato-Baked Eggs. The hash contained Poached Eggs, Summer Corn, Shishitos, Butter Biscuit, and Pepper Creme Fraiche. Perfect mix of flavors and textures. The pieces of cornbread on top of the hash was surprisingly my favorite part. On the second dish, eggs were baked into Creamy Polenta and Braised Pork Belly and served with a side of Avocado Toast. Also quite delicious. The polenta was not too creamy, and the sauce was not too tomato-y.

Again, the service was great. We were even asked about our food allergies after ordering our food. The decor is also gorgeous, with a giant plant thing in the middle of a restaurant that reaches up to the ceiling... and wooden boomerangs adorning the walls. Would highly recommend Stones Throw for the food, service, and overall experience. Solid five stars.
author: Stefanie C.

description:
AMAZING AMAZING AMAZING. 

The food is amazing. The service is amazing. 

I came here a year ago for an office party and have been dreaming of the food ever since. I finally came back and everything was as perfect as I remembered.  I got the squid in pasta, pate, octopus, burger, and worms in dirt.

First, the pate is the best thing you will ever eat. It's served with this warm pretzel bread. The pate is creamy and rich and delicious.  If I was dying tomorrow, this would be the last thing I'd want to eat. It's that good. 

The squid ink pasta is the best dish I have ever eaten in my life. You cannot go wrong with this. I would be lying if I said I didn't seriously consider if it'd be appropriate to lick the bowl.  Pro tip: the squid ink pasta can be served as a full sized entree and you 10/10 want it as an entree.  You're welcome. 

The octopus was phenomenal. It had a charred taste but didn't taste burnt. It was cooked perfectly not even a little chewy and overdone. 

The burger... I have never seen meat that moist. It was amazing. There's this pickled carrot relish in it that really worked so well. And the sauce they served it with.. I was scared it would ruin the taste of the burger but no, like everything else it was amazing. 

Worms in dirt- this came with a green apple sorbet and brownies over a chocolate crumble and gelee worms.  I'm the kind of person that doesn't do sorbet- if I'm going to eat a frozen dessert I want a heavy creamy gelato.  But this sorbet changed my life. It was so refreshing I would actually crave this more than I do ice cream. 

The only negative thing I have to say about this place is that I will never be able to enjoy other food again because nothing would ever compare.
author: Ashley A.

description: Ambiance, Service, Food, and Environment all hit the mark in my book! It's difficult to find restaurants that can maintain consistency across the board! We went here with some out of town friends and had a delightful culinary experience. Our waiter and hostess were both warm, personable and genuine. The menu consisted of shared items as well as entrees. Desserts were also the on point! It's cute because they feature different childhood favorite desserts ... but more elevated! Ohhh so good!
author: Kay H.

description: Hosted our management team dinner at Stones Throw last week and I cannot express how great of a time we had. Spoke with Tai in the weeks leading up to the dinner and she was beyond wonderful in helping plan everything from table location to wine list. The staff was fantastic - not too overbearing but always there when we needed them to be. On top of the great service, the food was excellent! Highly recommend the family style tasting menu if you have a big group (we had a party of 14).
author: Kathryn L.

description: Ordered risotto, with mushroom and chive. Bite into sand twice while eating it. Politely told the waiter , who is kind enough to go back and report to the kitchen. He came back apologized for "maybe" the mushrooms were not fully washed, but didn't offer any other gesture of hospitality that one usually gets under the circumstance. Was the second time here. Won't be here again.
author: Blue B.

description:
Oh man, what DIDN'T we eat on our recent group dinner at Stones Throw? I'll try to remember everything, but even if you don't want to read through my dissection of this amazing dinner, all you really need to know is that this place is wonderful.

To start, their craft cocktail list is short but definitely sweet. They also have a pages-long beer menu if that's more your style.

Okay, so the food. I'm sure I'm forgetting something, but here's the run-down:

Soft pretzels + pate: the pretzels were warm and soft and the pate was deeeeelicious. Huge fan!
Smoked fish and peas + tortilla chips: really delightful and fresh-tasting. My only wish is that there was more of it!
Custard bread thing: I feel like a chump for not really remembering exactly what this was, but it was tasty. The custard spread was a little bit strange texturally, so if you're a texture-freak this may not be for you, but otherwise, it was very good.
Pork belly: Fatty but super delicious.
Squid ink pasta with seafood: Had a nice little kick to it and great flavor! A favorite amongst our table.
Fish: I had expected the skin to be a little crispier, but the fish itself was beautifully cooked and flavorful.
Steak: PERFECTION. I could have eaten 6 plates of this.
PB & J Beignets: Such a fun twist on dessert! The beignets were fluffy and delicious, and the pb & j sauces were lightened up and just a touch of additional sweetness.
Cherry poptart: Always fun to see homemade poptarts out at restaurants, and this had a delightful presentation. I'd go for the PB&J donuts though if I had to pick just one.

So there you have it, an entire smorgasbord of delectableness. 10/10 would return to Stones Throw in an instance. Thanks for the great pick, Tara L.!
author: Gretchen F.

description: This had been on my list for a while, and finally got to try it last Thursday with a group of friends.  Service was very good - friendly and attentive, but not overbearing.  Food was good.  We split the four appetizers/starters they had on the menu - I liked the sturgeon mouse a lot.  My husband and I split the duck and it was pretty good, though a bit tougher than I like.  That said the portions were hearty and splitting it (along with the appetizers) was definitely enough food to satisfy me.  I really wanted to try the pea soup too (not sure if it was served hot or cold, though I was hoping the latter!), but didn't get a chance to.  For dessert, we had the PB&J doughnuts - though they were really beignets; our friends had the choco-tacos.  The portion size on the desserts was smaller than expected, but were pretty tasty.
author: Jeff A.

description: Husband and I chose to dine at Stones Throw for a belated Valentine's dinner while visiting San Francisco. We were extremely satisfied with the food, wine, and service. The scallops and the risotto dishes were delicious and the wine was divine. Great date night spot and reasonable prices for the quality of food. The desserts are very creative, we had the cheesecake and were very pleased!
author: Kelli W.

description: I think that the new chef is not as good as the previous one...and the prices went up.....a bit disappointing....
author: Dario P.

description:
Don't you hate when you want to look up your yelp review to see what you had last time, and realize you didn't even post one.  Ugh, how could I, especially when I absolutely loved Stones Throw.  This was my birthday treat this year and from the moment I walked in, the service was on point.  A happy birthday card was already on the table waiting for me!  Great start, am I right?  

My best foodie friends brought me here with my hunny, and we went to town!  We ate so much that I'm not sure if we didn't have something on the menu to be honest.  Highlights to me were the squid ink conchiglie pasta, the duck pate and mousse, the puffed potato and eggs, and the corn cannelloni with gnudi.  We also indulged in the oysters, crispy soft shelled crab, pork belly and crispy pig ears, pan roasted salmon, duck breast and roasted rib eye.  Dessert came with another happy birthday message on the plate of peanut butter and jelly donuts and key lime tart with mojito sorbet.

This place was such a nice experience.  Not only was service relaxed and friendly, but they were very good about timing of dishes, as well as giving us plenty of time to really enjoy our food and have good conversations with our party.  You can see that it is a real neighborhood gem. 

I'm so looking forward to coming here again.  Also, I hear they are opening a new place in Hayes Valley.  If it's even half as good as this place, I'm definitely there.
author: Maria S.

description:
Holy cow, mindblowingly creative and delicious! Came here for the fancy dinner of a weekend bachelorette party in the city, and everyone had the best time. 

AMBIANCE:
- Modern homey. Small and large tables available. Nice space for group in the back. 
- Open kitchen was cool where we could see the magic happen
- Felt very young and creative, innovative

SERVICE:
- Food came out quick and seamlessly
- Servers were very kind, and offered up perfect suggestions for a second bottle of wine to ease us through the remainder of our night

FOOD: We had the $55 Prix Fixe, which was so delicious and included all of the below. 
Snacks:
- Duck Pate & Mousse with french's mustard, cornichons, warm soft pretzel. This was amazing. It comes in the most beautiful rectangle of pate and mousse, topped with the mustard and cornichon shavings. The pretzel was soft and the perfect palate for the pate. The taste was rich, but not overwhelming. The texture was soft and buttery. Amazing.
- Puffed Potato & Eggs with cauliflower mousse, chives, crispy chicken skin. This is one of the most famous starters from Stones Throw, and I can totally see why. Each puffed potato is filled with runny egg and flash fried (I think) leaving an incredible mix of textures in each bite. It's warm and rich.
-Sturgeon Mousse with fried capers, dill, green apple shavings, and rye lavash. This was my favorite dish of the night! Totally unexpected, it blew me away. It wasn't fishy at all, and the texture of the mousse itself was not too thick. The flavors, with the crunchy capers and tart apple shavings, melded into perfection to bring out the exact right hints of sturgeon. I definitely snuck more than my fare share of this dish :)
- Smoked Cheddar "Fondue" with Brussels Sprouts, Grilled Firebrand Bread. This dish was also delicious. I thought it was going to be normal...melted cheese, and bread (don't get me wrong, this is always a winning combo for me), but the roasted brussels sprouts and other toppings in the cheese made it inventive and unexpected. Texture is thinner than nacho cheese, almost like a coating rather than a dip.

Starters: 
- Squid Ink Conchiglie Pasta with spicy capers, clams, calamari, shrimp, tender greens. This is another "must have" favorite dish of Stones Throw, and I totally can see why. The squid ink pasta is fresh and the perfect texture. The seafood mix is not overwhelming at all, and each bit was cooked to perfection -- no rubbery texture. You mix it all up at the start to get al the flavors to meld in the right way.
- Salt Baked Beet & Fennel Salad with tempura broccolini, rye lavash, horseradish creme, lemon-dill vinaigrette. This was a lovely fall salad. There were persimmons added to ours as they're in full season right now. The beets were sweet but not overwhelming. 
- Seared Tombo Tuna with calamari, avocado, shishito Peppers, Jicama, Agua Chile. One of the most beautiful presentations of food, the tuna is tender and cooked for the exact right amount. It falls apart at the touch of your fork. The agua chile is light, but still flavorful, and is the perfect accompaniment to the fresh seafood and avocados. The shishito peppers are seared, which adds a great smokiness to the dish.

Mains:
- Olive-oil Poached Salmon with Parsnip-Clam 'Chowder', Fall Root Vegetables, Crispy Salmon Skin. This was a delight as well. The perfect bite-sized portion of salmon, it was crispy skin and tender fish. The chowder was a nice base for the fish, adding a simple layer of moisture.
- Roasted Berkshire Pork Loin with White Bean Cassoulet, Crispy Pig's Ears, Ham Hock Jus. This was my least favorite of the dishes in the tasting menu. It was tender, but there wasn't as much flavor as I would have liked from a pork loin. That said, it was still good.
- Duo of beef ribeye and braised shortrib with Potato Pave, Creamed Kale, Chanterelle Mushrooms, Summer Truffle. This was my second favorite dish of the night. The beef was so juicy and tender, and was cooked perfectly. Again, all the flavors were a perfect harmony in each bite. 

Desserts:
- Peanut Butter & Jelly Donuts - this is their traditional American staple dessert, done fancy. Instead of donuts, there are fresh-fried beignets with real sugar instead of powdered. The peanut butter has real toasted peanuts and the grape jelly is smeared on the plate for dipping.
-Toasted marshmallow, rice krispy treats, yuzu sorbet, pickled persimmons - a nice light dessert.
- Quince gummy worms in dirt with green apple sorbet and fresh pomegranate seeds. Very rich and chocolatey. 

I would HIGHLY recommend the prix fixe meal for any group dining. It included so much of their amazing menu for such an affordable price. Food is timed well and executed to perfection. And there is SO MUCH FOOD. Portions are generous and everyone left food-coma full. We actually went back to our airBnB and took a 2 hour nap before going out for the night, because we were that stuffed! Great food, great atmosphere, great value!
author: Tiffany D.

description:
I looked forward to eating here for months and finally made a reservation for our anniversary. Sadly, I was pretty disappointed after hearing so many good things. 

What we loved
-Beautiful restaurant, simple, spacious
-Excellent service
-Lovely presentation of all dishes (including a customized dessert plate for our anniversary)
-Puff Potato & Eggs!!
-Summer Squash Panzanella

What we didn't love
-Duo of Beef Ribeye and Braised Short Rib- ribeye was very chewy and the short ribs had very little flavor
-Ricotta & Nettle Ravioli- very innovative dish, but not a whole lot of substance. Pretty basic flavors that didn't mess very well in my opinion

I'd love to go back and give this place another try and maybe order something else.
author: Cameron S.

description:
I waffled between 3 and 4 stars, but I'm in a holiday mood so I'm rounding up. 

A nice, quiet neighborhood restaurant. Most of the people here looked like they were on dates, but I came with a bunch of old friends from college. 

We got the octopus, smoked cheddar fondue, puffed potatoes, 2x squid ink pasta, persimmon salad, seared ahi tuna, short ribs, worms in dirt, and P&J donuts. Overall, I thought the food was decent. My favorite was the puffed potatoes, shortribs, and donuts. Persimmon salad and worms in dirt were awful though, so I'd avoid those. My table loved the squid ink pasta -- it was spicier than I thought it'd be, which isn't a ding on the dish since I like spicy, but I didn't love how the kick blended in with the seafood and rest of the flavors. Portions were a little smaller than I expected.  

Service was attentive, and the place wasn't too busy (we went on a Tuesday night).
author: Elizabeth L.

description: Terri and i came on a rainy night and had some very interesting small dishes.  Red Wines by the glass were exceptional
author: Wylie T.

description:
Get it all. Just go ahead and order everything.

Did I try everything? Well, no. But I feel fairly confident that just about everything you choose to order here will be impressive in some way or another, albeit taste or presentation. Dish after dish, the group I was dining with marveled at each delicious, and creative course that we enjoyed. 

Ironically, one of my favorite offerings was one that I least expected to like. I'm typically not big on pate, but the duck pate was outstanding. The puffed potato and egg was also just incredible. I think I was doing little happy dances under the table with my feet and potentially humming songs I don't know while I ate both of these.

And how can you go wrong with fresh peanut butter and jelly donuts? That's right. You can't.

Anyway, this review is a long time coming but it's still one of the best meals I've had over the past few years.
author: Tara L.

description:
Simple, non complicated, serviceable, your run of the mill dishes prepared in a hipsters infested neighborhood bistro. It proudly serves up Californian fusion cuisine in a creative and thoughtful manner in Russian Hill that attracts youngish, well to do diners. 

Contradiction is intended. 

In San Francisco, in particular, restaurants that serve high quality food are aplenty. It's very competitive, mind you, and if they were located elsewhere, say the middle of the America, everyone of them would simply rock your world, it's top notch. Plus Californian cuisine has that signature Asian influence or localvore micro greens element. It was coined by Alice Waters years ago, and it has taken the country by a storm via a food revolution ever since. Now everyone and their grandma are duplicating that success recipe. And I do mean EVERYONE: from Bangalore to Bali to Bergen to Santorini to Malaga to Berlin to Stockholm to Paris to Nice and London, and anything and everything in between.

But, you are in San Francisco, you kind of expect every meal to taste like this - Yes like you would expect in many parts of France. The standard is high. And therefore, by that standard, this food is  serviceable, but it's not unique. It's your typical bistro setting that serves up high quality Californian cuisine. Put a positive spin on it, it's a quintessential San Francisco experience. A great meal in a great neighborhood with spotless service. You can look out to the cable car, and hold the gaze of your lover, who lives in this neck of woods.  Since the beginning of the time (so you think), he's been madly in love with you, and you him. And tonight being a date night, you two shall gather in this familiar neighborhood and enjoy a nice meal, with wine to boot. That's what real, rare, therapist-approved, once a life time romance is all about. And how else can you express such love without the backdrop of one such restaurant? 

Cue the watercolor painting: a fanciful, albeit understated meal (by San Franciscan standard), good wine, great companion, fantastic weather (again by San Francisco standard), the bell rings as the cable car approaches to a stop, and the fog horn is sounding, ever so faintly - the fog is about to roll in. 

Duck pate is good. Fish is always a winner. So is the duck. Order the Pinot.

Think: when did San Francisco become Paris? If not in every aesthetics and every aspect, certainly in price.  And would this average bill of $120, dinner for 2 tab go up or down in the next five years? And should one feel guilty about it for having enjoyed, yet another, one such meal?

Don't think. Just eat.
author: Victoria E.

description:
I've been wanting to try Stones Throw for a while, on the recommendation of a coworker.  My boyfriend and I found ourselves in the area and came here without a reservation.  We were a little confused, as the door decal and the posted menu said different opening times (5 pm vs 5:30 pm), so we came at 5:35, and were greeted warmly and invited to sit at the bar while the hostess checked if they could accommodate us.  The first thing I noticed here was that they had a fantastic beer selection and a very well thought out decor and motif.  

We were seated just a few minutes after we arrived, and service was very fast.  Maybe they were trying to get us out before the first reservation, but I was starving and happy that food was coming as quickly as it did.  

YELLOWTAIL & SCALLOP CEVICHE
Shrimp, Cucumber, Coconut, Jalapeno, Cilantro and rice chips 
So fresh, and the coconut - which could have either been really bad or really good - was surprisingly great!

TAMARIND-GLAZED BEEF RIBEYE 
Crispy Black Rice, Broccolini, Toasted Garlic, Scallion
Presentation was beautiful, with the red meat over the vibrant green sauce.  Seasoning was fantastic and the rice was crispy.

BUTTERNUT SQUASH RAVIOLI 
Ricotta Gnudi, Brussels Sprout Pesto, Truffle, Sage
So delicious!!  The ravioli and gnudi together gave it just enough carby richness.  The brussels sprouts and butternut squash gave it a pop of color.

We were too full for dessert, but appreciated the presentation.  They give you a menu with chunky wood pencils, looking like a tree branch with a pencil tip on the end.  They ask you to write your favorite childhood dessert, and if they turn it into a dish on the menu, the chef may ask you to return to try it.  Cute concept.  I love all the thought they put into making Stones Throw a welcoming and consistent place.
author: Christina G.

description:
Came here for brunch this morning. It is a nice trendy restaurant in San Francisco. All of the dishes were good. I was a bit disappointed that they don't have hot chocolate. They only offer coffee, tea, and a bunch of alcoholic beverages. I would highly recommend them adding hot chocolate since people come here for brunch during the weekend and they have a section in their menu dedicated for sweet food items.

PUFFED POTATO & EGGS ($8)
Cauliflower Mousse, Chives, Crispy Chicken Skin
This was really good. Loved the combination of all of the ingredients. 

CINNAMON-SPICED MONKEY BREAD ($14)
Bananas, Caramel, Cream Cheese Frosting, Toasted Pecans
I ordered this dish. So sweet! The bread was soft but the outside part was crispy.

DUCK CONFIT HASH ($17)
Poached Eggs, Butternut Squash, Brussels Sprouts, Toasted Foccacia
My boyfriend ordered this dish. I'm a fan of duck so this dish was really good. Everything was perfect. The ingredients went well together. 

I will definitely come here again for dinner next time. I hope they'll have hot chocolate added in their menu for brunch.
author: Jennifer B.

description:
I came here for my birthday, and wow it does not disappoint. Ordered the squid ink pasta, potato egg puffs (so typical), short ribs, and scallops. Not only is the presentation beautiful, but the food is a time bomb in your mouth. When you bite into the potato puffs, you have to wait for a while for the cheesy egginess to sink into your tongue. I licked some of the sauce that came with the scallops off my fork, and it literally took a few seconds before I tasted the zing. 

The service goes above and beyond. They left me a sweet handwritten birthday card, and I got to blow out candles on this adorable mini version of their peanut butter and jelly donuts dessert. Also, someone came by to wipe down our tables and replace cutlery after every dish. Our water glasses got filled before we even noticed they were empty. Bottomless water! Woohoo! Doesn't take magic to make it happen!

I loved all the food, especially the potato puffs. I wish I could've had them all for myself! The squid ink pasta was a little on the salty side, but the sauce was interesting. The ribs were also a bit underwhelming. But the food is nevertheless delicious, and I've really only experienced this kind of service in a few places. A fun and colorful experience!
author: Sophie W.

description:
I loved the food, the service could use a bit more attention.  This place was busy on a Saturday night, lots of people at the bar, all the tables booked! 

We started with the puffed potatoes and eggs, the octopus salad, and then I had the ravioli and my husband the burger. 

The potatoes were yummy, rich and just melted in our mouths, great starter on a cold winter night.  The octopus was great, grilled to perfection and so tender, this is an easy one to screw up.  The burger was juicy and very well done, could have had fries on the side instead of the tater tots though.  The ravioli was tender, yummy and rich.  The waiter asked if I liked them, loved them but it was too much for me. 

I'd love to have a few more things on the menu to choose from, maybe a foie would be great too and some veggies to mix things up.
author: Inga W.

description: The squid ink pasta here is to DIE FOR. So many flavors and so well balanced. Even though it's listed as an appetizer, you can ask for it in an entree size. TRUST ME, it's the right choice.
author: Rachel Z.

description:
Yum! Where do I begin. I'm so glad I finally got to try this place as its been on my list! 

First impression:  nice decor, there's also a bar area with stools to sit on. 

Let's get straight to business! My order went as follows: 

1) Oysters-very fresh and such a great way to clean the palate. 

2) Summer cup drink- very refreshing and you can taste the jalapeño!

3) Potato Balls- Such a yummy starter. Not sure how they get the yolk in there but it's so good! Especially with the cauliflower. 

4) Summer squash salad- not great, not something I'd order again.  The portion was pretty small even though it was a starter and it didn't stand out in flavor. 

5) Squid Ink Pasta- MY FAVORITE PART of the meal! This was everything and more. Really great flavor, the seafood (shrimp, squid) was not dry either and the only complaint is that the portion is too small for its greatness. 

6) Roasted duck breast- Very heavy but tender! The skin was crispy and the duck was cooked well. There was a small "duck tamale" in between which caught me by surprise. 

7) Peanut butter jelly donuts- Not bad, basically beignets with jelly and peanut butter dabs on the plate for you to dip. I could've done with just the beignets and ice cream. 

Will be back but probably not soon. The bill for everything listed above plus one more drink was about $198. Pricy but enjoyable. 

This place has absolutely no parking.  I would uber or lyft here unless you live nearby. :)
author: Shelly W.

description: I would give this place a 4.5 rating. It's a cute spot in Russian Hill. My bf loves this place so decided to take me here for a date. We didn't make reservations so we sat at the bar. The bartender was pleasant and gave good food suggestions. He didn't steer us wrong. The squid ink pasta was decadent and delicious. It was great that it was an appetizer portion. I was impressed with their grilled octopus app. This was my first time having it and it was fantastic. We also had their hamachi like crudo. It was so fresh and a generous fish portion. We indulged on the PB&J beignets. They were nice and warm. My bf had their ants on a log dessert which he enjoyed. It was a fairly light dessert after a nice meal. Definitely make reservations if you want a table. I would come back and see what new items they have on their menu.
author: Daniela B.

description:
I've come to Stones Throw about 3-4 times now in the past year - and have loved every. single. time. The food is first of all amazingggggg - two brunches, and one dinner but all echo the sentiments of great food, prepared to perfection. Just a few recommendations...
1. Potato puff - must. get. this. I could eat 10 of these (each app comes with 4 spread out over cauliflower mousse with bacon and chive shavings). It comes with runny egg yolk (which they actually make by combining with gelatin and freezing, and flash frying it for a few seconds) and is coated with some chicken skin crust. 
2. Donuts - such a lovely sweet treat that does not break the calorie bank. Seasonal so I've had some different ones each time.
3. Duck confit hash - brunch only I believe. So delicious. In my opinion the best thing on the brunch menu.
4. Squid ink spaghettini - Save yourself (and your party) the agony of only ordering one of these and having to share. Get your own! so so so so worth it. 
5. Pork belly - All the pork entrees I've had here have been phenomenal. Whether it's on the brunch or dinner menu, all have been excellently cooked. 

I cannot wait to come back!
author: June L.

description: This place has been on my list for awhile. Nice and cozy, great service. Perfect spot for a date. Food was plated beautifully. Our dishes were good but I feel there are many places in the city with this price point that are better. Glad we had a chance to try but not worth the trek unless you live in the area.
author: Amy J.

description:
What a gem! Great service! Great drinks... I had some concoction with fennel , honey and bubbles ... electric ??? Anyways very good! Potato eggs puffs , hello! Delicious ! Tuna trombo? Do not miss it! Our main courses were great! Why have we not been here before? Oh wait...dessert ! Pb and  Jelly donuts... homey, delightful, fresh!
People of SF , you are lucky you have stones throw!
author: La S.

description:
- Great ambiance!
- Wonderful service.  The team felt genuine in its desire to help and was really happy when we enjoyed our meal
- The sturgeon mousse was delicate, smooth, AND distinct.  Definitely a hard feat to pull off
- The smoked cheddar fondue was ok by itself, but the onions and brussels sprouts kicked it up a notch
- The short ribs were ridiculously good.  I need to learn to cook these this well.  Usually short ribs aren't very firm.  That's part of the treat.  These had a nice crust, yet when digging your fork in, it was just as tender.  The crust had amazing flavor.  The slight hint of horseradish made this dish achieve amazing
author: Mike F.

description:
TL; DR: Five stars for flawless food (even though some items weren't exactly my cup of tea). 

Had my yearly CM Week team dinner here and my boss always chooses the best restaurants (umm... hello Zaytinya in DC!), so needless to say I was stoked. I had looked at the menu prior to that night, and was a little unsure of what I would order. The menu was a little adventurous for me, and I gotta admit I was a little worried. To my surprise, she had arranged for us to do a chef's tasting. No ordering required! Perfect. 

In all, we tasted the Atricokes A La Barigoule, Puffed Potato and Egg, Three Layer 'Chips and Dip', Duck Paté and Mousse, Squid Ink Pasta, Warm 'Banh Mi Style' Pork Belly, Seared Tombo Tuna, Striped Bass, Pork Loin, and Duo of Beef Ribeye and Braised Shortrib. For dessert? Peanut butter and jelly donuts, pop tarts, and the banana split. Not gonna lie to you, the dessert was my favorite part (this is nothing new if you follow my reviews and know about my intense sweet tooth!). Anywho, everyone seemed to be very impressed by all the food offerings. Service was solid throughout the entire meal. They even brought separate meat plates (that were cooked longer) out to our pregnant coworker so she could enjoy them too! I'd say the standouts were the donuts, pop tart, puffed potatoes, and chips and dip. I'm still thinking about those dishes almost a week later and would definitely go back for any of them. 

When in San Francisco, I'd say that this is a solid spot to get some adventurous eats!
author: Lauri W.

description: My boyfriend and I came here for my anniversary and it did not did not disappoint. The food is phenomenal and the service was spectacular. The waitress was knowledgeable about literally every single dish and she clearly took pride is her ability to deliver great service! To finish the night they had some fun dessert options and we we're very satisfied with our experience.
author: Phillip P.

description:
Before anything, their **Squid Ink Pasta was AMAZING!

The whole dining experience was a 4.5 Star. Everything was really good. Service was great. Dim lighting with warm decor. Reservations recommended. 
**Puffed Potato & Eggs with Cauliflower Mousse was okay. Probably the least favorite dish. Was hoping for a little more flavor and crispier. 
**Duck Pate & Mousse with Soft Pretzel. WOW!!! The pate was delicious. Perfect blend with the mustard and cornichons. The pretzel was warm and soft. I needed more, delicious! 
**SQUID INK CONCHIGLIE PASTA is made with Spicy Capers, Clams, Calamari, Shrimp, Tender Greens. It's really the best squid Ink pasta I EVER HAD!! Must try from someone who doesn't really like squid ink before Stones Throw. So much flavor, so good. It was the best dish of the night!!
**PORK BELLY - Good texture, good flavor and it was crunchy. Comes with 3 pieces. 
**Beef Ribeye and Braised Shortribs - Plated with Potatoes, Cabbage, Onion and Chimichurri. I love it because you get a little of both. Steak was cook to its best, medium rare and the rib was soft and tender. Good flavor.

As for dessert, we got their Blackberry Crisp, cheesecake. It was super yummy. Not too sweets. Yum!
author: Sandy B.

description:
This place is a neighborhood gem! Yes, parking sucks and you might end up parking blocks away and walk up a hill. But, it was worth it!  
We had reservations but since there were a couple of seats open at the bar, we decided to be were the action (and the alcohol) was. 
Tyler was the most gracious host. He interacted with us. He made sure that we were comfortable at the bar (not once were our water glasses empty).  He gave us great recommendations on what to eat being it was our first time. 
For starters, we had the duck pâté and mousse, and the puffed potato and eggs. They were both wonderful. My girlfriend enjoyed the pâté more than I (she likes mustard more than I). But we both enjoyed the puffed potato, especially the cauliflower mousse that they were on top off.  
Next we had the squid ink conchiglie pasta and the charred Spanish octopus.  The octopus was seared nicely without having that burnt flavor and it was still tender. The squid ink pasta was the best meal of the night!  We enjoyed it so much we ordered it again!  The pasta was al dente. The sauce had enough seafood and greens to complete the dish. It had a nice spicy kick to it as well. 
For our main, we shared the pan-roasted steelhead trout. It was perfectly cooked!  The skin was crispy while the meat remained juicy. The champagne and roe burre blanc, along with the bed of apple and celery root, complemented each other. 
Dessert was a perfect ending to a fantastic dinner!  I would definitely go back!
author: Jay F.

description:
Aghh, I've been eye-ing this restaurant for the past 1.5 years, only to find out that it wasn't as great as I had expected it to be. Did I just not order the right things, or maybe it's the inconsistency of the plates (since a lot of people seemed to enjoy this place)? I don't know... but I felt like the dishes were a hit or miss for me. 

+ duck pate and mousse - my first time trying pate, and I loved it! I have a very picky palette, and I'm glad my boyfriend forced me to try it. Don't forget to eat it with the bread to get the full experience!

+ squid ink pasta - my favorite dish! I loved how they added clams, calamari, shrimp, and greens! Flavor was rich, and I found myself constantly dipping the pasta in the the white sauce.

+ banh mi style pork belly - was good, but it also tasted like every other banh mi plate I've had at other nice restaurants.

+ duo of beef ribeye & shortrib - this was supposed to be the main course, yet it was my least favorite dish! The meat was a soggy kind of chewy... the kind that I have to chew a million times before forcing it down my throat.
